text: Above Midtown section of the city. It is early afternoon, hot mid-summer day. The city is sun-sunblanched white and its drifted-up noises are muted in blanched their own ech We fly low, heading in a downtown direction, passing over traffic-clogged streets, parking lots, white business  buildings, neatly patterned residential districts. As we  approach downtown section, the character of the city begi to change. It is darker and shabby with age and industry. see railroad tracks, smokestacks, wholesale fruit-and- vegetable markets, old municipal buildings, empty lots.   vegetable The very geography seems to give us a climate o nefariousness, of back-doorness, dark and shadowy. And se We fly lower and faster now, as if seeking out a specific location. A skinny, high old hotel comes into view. On it exposed brick side great painted letters advertise "Trans Low Weekly Rates-Radio in Every Room." We pause long enou to establish the shoddy character of this hotel. Its open curtainless windows, its silent resigned look so  characteristic of such hole-and-corner hotels. We move fo with purposefulness and-toward a certain window. The sash raised as high as it can go, but the shade is pulled down three or four inches of the inside sill, as if the occupa of the room within wanted privacy but needed air. We are  close now, so that only the lower half of the window fram is in shot. No sounds come from within the room. Suddenly, we tip downward, go to the narrow space between shade and sill, peep into the room. A young woman is stretched out on the mussed bed. She wea a full slip, stockings, no shoes. She lies in and attitud of physical relaxation, but her face, seen in the dimness the room, betrays a certain inner-tension, worrisome  conflicts. She is MARY CRANE, an tension, attractive girl nearing the end of her twenties and her rope. A man stands beside the bed, only the lower half of his f visible. We hold on this tableau for a long moment, then  start forward. As we pass under the window shade,

A small room, a slow fan buzzing on a shelf above the nar bed. A card of hotel rules is pasted on the mirror above bureau. An unopened suitcase and a woman's large, straw o top handbag are on the bureau. On the table beside the bed there are a container of Coco Cola and an unwrapped, untouched egg-salad sandwich. Ther is no radio. The man standing by the bed, wearing only trousers, T-shi and sox, is SAM LOOMIS, a good-looking, sensual shirt man with warm humorous eyes and a compelling smile. He is blo his neck and face with a thin towel, and is staring down Mary, a small sweet smile playing about his mouth. Mary k her face turned away from him. After a moment, Sam drops the towel, sits on the bed, lea over and takes Mary into his arms, kisses her long and wa holds her with a firm possessiveness. The kiss is disturb and finally interrupted by the buzzing closeness of an  inconsiderate fly. Sam smiles, pulls away enough to allow Mary to relax again against the pillow. He studies her, f at her unresponsiveness, then speaks in a low, intimate,  playful voice.

Never did eat your lunch, did you. Mary looks at his smile, has to respond, pulls him to her kisses him. Then, and without breaking the kiss, she swin her legs over the side of the bed, toe-searches around, f her shoes, slips her feet into searches them. And finally pulls away and sits up.

I better get back to the office.   These extended lunch hours give my  boss excess acid. She rises, goes to the bureau, takes a pair of small earr out of her bag, begins putting them on, not bothering or  perhaps not wanting to look at herself in the mirror. Sam watches her, concerned but unable to inhibit his cheery,  humorous good mood. Throughout remainder of this scene, t occupy themselves with dressing, hair-combing, etc.
Call your boss and tell him you're  taking the rest of the afternoon  off. It's Friday anyway... and hot.
(soft sarcasm)
What do I do with my free afternoon,  walk you to the airport?
(meaningfully)
We could laze around here a while  longer.
Checking out time is three P.M. Hotels  of this sort aren't interested in  you when you come in, but when your  time's up... (a small anguish)
Sam, I hate having to be with you in  a place like this.
I've heard of married couples who  deliberately spend occasional nights  in cheap hotels. They say it...
(interrupting)
When you're married you can do a lot  of things deliberately.
You sure talk like a girl who's been  married.
Sam!
I'm sorry, Mary. (after a moment)
My old Dad used to say 'when you  can't change a situation, laugh at  it.' Nothing ridicules a thing like  laughing at it.
I've lost my girlish laughter.
(observing)
The only girlish thing you have lost.
(a meaningful quiet,  then, with difficulty:)
Sam. This is the last time.
For what?
This! Meeting you in secret so we  can be... secretive! You come down  here on business trips and we steal  lunch hours and... I wish you wouldn't  even come.
Okay. What do we do instead, write  each other lurid love letters?
(about to argue, then  turning away)
I haven't time to argue. I'm a working  girl.
And I'm a working man! We're a regular  working-class tragedy! (he laughs)
It is tragic! Or it will be... if we  go on meeting in shabby hotels  whenever you can find a tax-deductible  excuse for flying down deductible  here...
(interrupting,  seriously)
You can't laugh at it, huh?
Can you?

Sure. It's like laughing through a  broken jaw, but... He breaks off, his cheeriness dissolved, goes to the wind tries to raise the shade. It sticks. He pulls at it. It comes down entirely, and the hot sun glares into the r revealing it in all its shabbiness and sordidness as if  corroborating Mary's words and attitude. Sam kicks at the fallen shade, laughs in frustration, grabs on to his humo again.
And besides, when you say I make tax- deductible excuses you make me out a  criminal.
(having to smile)
You couldn't be a criminal if you  committed a major crime.
I wish I were. Not an active criminal  but... a nice guy with the conscience  of a criminal. (goes close to mary,  touches her)
Next best thing to no conscience at  all.
(pulling away)
I have to go, Sam.
I can come down next week.
No.
Not even just to see you, to have  lunch... in public?
We can see each other, we can even  have dinner... but respectably, in  my house with my mother's picture on  the mantel and my sister helping me  broil a big steak for three!
And after the steak... do we send  Sister to the movies and turn Mama's  picture to the wall?
Sam! No!
(after a pause, simply)

All right. She stares at him, surprised at his willingness to contin the affair on her terms, as girls are so often surprised  when they discover men will continue to want them even af the sexual bait has been pulled in. Sam smiles reassuring places his hands gently on her arms, speaks with gentle a simple sincerity.
Mary, whenever it's possible, tax- deductible or not, I want to see  deductible you. And under any  conditions. (a smile)
Even respectability.
You make respectability sound...   disrespectful.
(brightly)
I'm all for it! It requires patience  and temperance and a lot of sweating- out... otherwise, though, it's only  hard work. (a pause)
But if I can see you, touch you even  as simply as this... I won't mind. He moves away and again the weight of his pain and proble crushes away his good humor. There is a quiet moment.

I'm fed up with sweating for people  who aren't there. I sweat to pay off  my father's debts... and he's in his  grave... I sweat to pay my ex-wife  alimony, and she's living on the  other side of the world somewhere.
(a smile)
I pay, too. They also pay who meet  in hotel rooms.
A couple of years and the debts will  be paid off. And if she ever re- marries, the alimony stops... and  then...
I haven't even been married once  yet!
Yeah, but when you do... you'll swing.
(smiling, then with a  terrible urgency)
Sam, let's go get married.
And live with me in a storeroom behind  a hardware store in Fairvale. We'll  have a lot of laughs. When I send my  ex-wife her money, you can lick the  stamps.
(a deep desperation)
I'll lick the stamps. He looks at her, long, pulls her close, kisses her lightl looks out the window and stares at the wide sky.

You know what I'd like? A clear,  empty sky... and a plane, and us in  it... and somewhere a private island  for sale, where we can run around  without our... shoes on.  And the  wherewithal to buy what I'd like. (he moves away,  suddenly serious)
Mary, you want to cut this off, go  out and find yourself someone  available.
I'm thinking of it.
(a cheerful shout)
How can you even think a thing like  that!
(picking up handbag,  starting for door)
Don't miss your plane.
Hey, we can leave together can't we?
(at door)
I'm late... and you have to put your  shoes on. Mary goes out quickly, closing door behind her. As Sam st down at his shoeless feet,
Shooting down at hotel entrance. Mary comes out, walks qu to a parked cab, gets in. The cab zooms up the awful stre
A small, moderately successful office off the main street cab pulls up at the curb. We see Mary get out of cab, pay driver, cross pavement to the office door.
Mary enters office, crosses to her desk, sits down, rubs temples, finally looks over at Caroline, a girl in the la of her teens.
Isn't Mr. Lowery back from lunch?
(a high, bright, eager- to-talk voice laced  to-with a vague Texan  accent)
He's lunching with the man who's  buying the Harris Street property,  you know, that oil lease man...  so  that's why he's late. (a pause, then, as  Mary does not respond  to the pointed thrust)
You getting a headache?
It'll pass. Headaches are like  resolutions... you forget them soon  as they stop hurting.
You got aspirins? I have something...  not aspirins, but (cheerfully takes  bottle of pills out  of desk drawer)
my mother's doctor gave these to me  the day of my wedding. (laughs)
Teddy was furious when he found out  I'd taken tranquilizers! She rises, starts for Mary's desk, pills in hand.
Were there any calls?

Teddy called.  Me... And my mother  called to see if Teddy called. Oh,  and your sister called to say she's  going to Tucson to do some buying  and she'll be gone the whole weekend  and... She breaks off, distracted by the SOUND of the door openi MR. LOWERY and his oil-lease client, TOM CASSIDY enter th office. Lowery is a pleasant, worried-faced man, big and trifle pompous. Cassidy is very faced loud and has a lunc hour load on. He is a gross man, exuding a kind of pitifu vulgarity.
Wow! Hot as fresh milk! You girls  should get your boss to air-condition  you up. He can afford it today. Lowery flashes an embarrassed smile at Mary, tries to lea Cassidy toward the private office.
Mary, will you get those copies of  the deed ready for Mr. Cassidy. Cassidy pauses beside Mary's desk, hooks a haunch onto th desktop, smiles a wet smile at Mary.
Tomorrow's the day! My sweet little  girl... (laughs as Mary looks  up at him)
Not you, my daughter!  A baby, and  tomorrow she stands up there and  gets her sweet self married away  from me! (pulling out wallet)
I want you to look at my baby.   Eighteen years old... and she's never  had an unhappy day in any one of  those years! (flashes photo)
Mary glances, cannot bring herself to smile or make some  remark, continues sorting out the deed copies, tries to i the man's hot-breath closeness.
Come on, Tom, my office is air- conditioned.
(ignoring Lowery)
You know what I do with unhappiness?  I buy it off! You unhappy?
Not inordinately. (puts deed copy into  Cassidy's too-close  hand)
I'm buying this house for my baby's  wedding present. Forty thousand  dollars, cash! Now that ain't buying  happiness, that's buying off  unhappiness! That penniless punk  she's marryin'... (laughs)
Probably a good kid... it's just  that I hate him. (looks at deed)
Yup! Forty thousand, says here... (to Lowery)

Casharoonie! He takes out of his inside pocket, two separate bundles o new $100 bills and throws them onto the desk, under Mary' nose. Caroline's eyes go wide at the sight of the gloriou green bundles of bills, and she comes close to the desk.  Cassidy leans terribly close to Mary, flicks through the  bills, laughs wickedly.
I never carry more than I can afford  to lose! (closer to Mary)
Count 'em!
(shocked, worried)
Tom... cash transactions of this  size! Most irregular...
So what? It's my private money! (laughs, winks, elbows  Lowery)
And now it's yours.
(staring at the money)
I declare!
(whispering)
I don't! That's how I'm able to keep  it! (laughs)
(hastily interrupting)
Suppose we just put this in the safe  and then Monday morning when you're  feeling good...
Speakin' of feeling good, where's  that bottle you said you had in your  desk... (laughs, as if having  given away Lowery's  secret)
Oops! (to Mary, patting her  arm)
Usually I can keep my mouth shut! He rises, reels toward Lowery's office, pauses, turns, sp to Mary, meaningfully.
Honest. I can keep any private  transaction a secret... any pri.... (stopped by Mary's  cold gaze)
Lowery! I'm dyin' of thirstaroonie! Lowery starts after him, pauses, turns to Mary. Cassidy h gone into Lower's office.
(quietly)

I don't even want it in the office  over the weekend. Put it in the safe  deposit box, at the bank, Mary. And  we'll get him to give us a check on  Monday - instead. He starts quickly away when it looks like Cassidy is goin to come and pull him bodily into the office. When the men are gone and the door is closed, Caroline picks up a bund smiles at it.

He was flirting with you. I guess he  noticed my wedding ring. Mary has put one bundle into a large envelope and takes t other from Caroline. When the bills are away, she puts th filled envelope in her handbag, notices the remaining dee copies on her desk, picks them up, goes to the private of door, knocks, starts to open door as:
Come in.
Mary opens door, looks in. Cassidy is drinking from a lar tumbler, winks at her without pausing in his drinking. Ma remains on threshold a moment, then crosses to the desk,  talking as she goes.
The copies. Mr. Lowery, if you don't  mind, I'd like to go right on home  after the bank. I have a slight...
You go right home!  Me and your boss  are going out to get ourselves a  little drinkin' done! (to Lowery)
Right?
(to Mary)
Of course. You feeling ill?
A headache.
You need a week-end in Las Vegas...  playground of the world!
I'm going to spend this week-end in  bed. (starts out)
(to Lowery)
Only playground that beats Las Vegas! Mary goes back out into the outer office, closes door.
Mary goes to her desk, takes the handbag, checks to make  sure the money-filled envelope is tucked well down into i During this:
Aren't you going to take the pills? (as Mary shakes her  head)
They'll knock that headache out.
I don't need pills... just sleep. She goes to the door.

A double bed in the foreground. We just see the far side the CAMERA SHOOTS across. Mary enters the scene, clad onl in her slip. Perhaps she is about to get into bed. Behind her is an open closet, but too dark inside for us to see contents. As Mary turns to the closet the CAMERA LOWERS t show a close view of the $40,000 in the envelope on our s of the bed. Mary takes a dress from the closet and starts to put it o as the CAMERA RETREATS to reveal a packed but not yet clo suitcase also on the bed. Mary zips up her dress and then brings some final garments from the closet. She comes around to the suitcase and puts them on the top Mary works with haste and in tension, as if acting on an  impulse which might vanish as quickly as it came. The suitcase filled now, she checks around the room, then takes her handbag to the bed, puts in the money-filled  envelope, and then slams the suitcase shut. Then filled s looks at her small bedroom desk, goes to it, removes a sm file-envelope from one of the drawers. It is one of those brown envelopes in which one keeps important papers and  policies and certificates. She checks its contents briefl puts it on the bed, opens another desk drawer, takes out bank book, tosses it on the bed. Then she packs both the  file-envelope and the bank book, into her handbag, takes quick last look around the room, picks up the handbag and the suitcase and goes out of the room.

A two-car garage. One car is gone. Mary's car is parked i the driveway. The CAMERA is low enough so that we can eas read the Arizona number plate in the foreground. Mary comes out of house, starts for the trunk, intending put the suitcase in, changes her mind, places the suitcas and her handbag on the front seat, gets in, starts the ca begins to back out of driveway.

We are close on Mary's car, shooting in at her troubled,  guilty face. She seems to be driving with that excess car of one who does not wish to be stopped for a minor traffi irregularity. She stops for a red light at a main  intersection.
We see Lowery and Cassidy crossing the street, passing ri in front of Mary's car.
Mary freezes.
Cassidy, glancing into car, sees Mary, lets out a cheery  exclamation, elbows Lowery. Lowery turns, sees Mary, smil pleasantly, pulls Cassidy on.
Mary watches the entire exchange with a look of stony hor on her face.

Now we look closely at Lowery. As he reaches the curb, a  small confusion brightens his face. He remembers that Mar intended to "spend the weekend in bed." He considers,  curiously, turns, looks back at her, a slight frown on hi face.
Mary sees the pause and the look.
For a moment it even looks as if Lowery might be meaning cross back to the car.
Mary's tension is unbearable. And at that moment we hear shrill shriek of the traffic cop's whistle. Mary zooms the car away.
Mary in car, driving, safely away from town. Her look is  less tense now, and more purposeful. After a moment, she  checks the fuel gauge, frowns, looks along highway for a station.
Approaching and leaving city limits.
Looks at gas gauge.

We see Mary's car drive in, come to a stop. There are no  other cars about, this being a gas station off the main  highway, and the attendant is obviously in the shack. Mar looks worried about having to make this stop, keeps her f turned away from the shack, not wishing it to be seen. No one comes and for a moment Mary considers driving on, if the emptiness of the station were a warning, an omen t she should listen to. But the gas registers almost empty. She has to blow her horn. A YOUNG MAN comes out of the shack, starts toward her car At that moment, we HEAR the RINGING of the TELEPHONE in t shack. The Attendant walks a few steps further, toward Ma car, then decides to go back and answer the phone. The ph insistent ringing unnerves Mary. She starts her car, zooms off. We see the Attendant, phone in hand, in the doorway of sh He looks after the departing car with little or no expres
The car grows smaller as it races up the road. The sun is setting. There is something vaguely ominous about the  darkening sky into which the car seems to be disappearing

The oncoming headlights hurt Mary's eyes. She is getting  sleepy and her vision is blurring. Her eyes close,  involuntarily, snap open again. She stretches than wide, if forcing them to stay open. The oncoming lights seem to glare to a point beyond endurance. She murmurs "Sam - Sam

We see Mary's car, dim in the early dawn, tilted on the s shoulder of the road, looking somehow sad and pathetic, l a child's thrown-away toy. And from this angle it would a that the car is empty. After a moment, during which there are no other vehicles  passing, we see, coming from the far distance, a HIGHWAY  PATROLMAN in a patrol car. He passes Mary's car, notes it apparent emptiness, U-turns, comes back up behind the car He gets out and approaches the driver's side window.
The Patrolman looks down into the car.
Mary turns with a start, sits up, is startled and unnerve by the sight of the Patrolman, and, as if by automatic re turns the ignition and presses down on the starter.
The Patrolman holds up his hand.
(startled)
Hold it there! Mary slams down on the brake, tries to pull herself toget The Patrolman raps again, less gently. Reluctantly, Mary rolls down the window. The Patrolman st her for a moment.
In quite a hurry.
Yes. (because he seems to  be awaiting an  explanation)
I didn't mean to sleep so long. I  was afraid I'd have an accident last  night, from sleepiness... so I decided  to pull over...
You slept here all night?
(a faint edge of  defensiveness)
Yes. As I said, I couldn't keep my  eyes...
(mere concern)
There are plenty of motels in this  area. You should have... I mean,  just to be safe...
I didn't intend to sleep all night! I just pulled over... have I broken  any laws?
No, m'am.
Then I'm free to go...?
(a pause)
Is anything wrong?
Of course not! Am I acting as if...  something's wrong?
(almost a smile)
Frankly, yes.
Please... I'd like to go...
Is there?
Is there what? (not waiting for an  answer)
I've told you there's nothing wrong...  except that I'm in a hurry and you're  taking up my time...
(interrupting, sternly)
Now wait just a moment! Turn your  motor off, please. Mary seems about to object, thinks better of it, turns of the ignition.
In the course of my duty, I never  "take up" anyone's time, whether  it's to give a warning, or a ticket,  or help! Believe that, M'am. (a little softer)
Now if you woke up on the wrong side  of... the car seat, that's one thing.  But when you act as if I've just  placed you under arrest...
I'm sorry.

No need to apologize... Mary starts the car, her face turned as if she wishes the matter were all settled and the Patrolman had already gon The Patrolman isn't exactly one of those civil servants w demands a thank-you, but he does feel her manner is a bit too abrupt. He calls:
Wait a minute!
(jamming down the  brake)
Now what? The Patrolman gazes at her a moment, then:
May I see your license?
Why?

Please. Mary pulls her handbag up from the floor, where she'd pla it when she stretched out for sleep. She puts her hand in it, rummages for her wallet, cannot find it. The Patrolman is staring at her. She glances at him nervo pokes in her bag a bit more, sighs, realizes she'll have remove some of its contents. Nervously, badly controlling her fear, she takes out the money-filled envelope, and th the important papers envelope, filled then a couple of ot items, places them on the seat, finally finds her wallet, opens it, hands it to him. He looks at the wallet, then a the car.
The Patrolman walks around to the front of the car, check the license plate, and returns.
The Patrolman peers in, checks the car registration on th steering wheel, returns Mary's wallet. She takes it, looks at him for a flicker of a moment. He says nothing. She starts ahead, fast.
The Patrolman stares after Mary as she drives off, then s back to his automobile.

She is quite shaken, realizes she caused herself a great  deal of trouble and placed herself in unnecessary danger. She is disturbed and angry and frightened at her inabilit to act normally under the pressure of guilt. As she drive she glances into her rear-view mirror.
The Patrolman is following in his automobile, keeping beh her at a matched speed.
She glances out at her surroundings.
The Freeway ahead.
She suddenly turns off the highway.
She checks her mirror.
The Patrolman is no longer following, has not turned off  after her.
She breathes a sigh of relief, thinks a moment, makes a q decision.

The big sign reads "California Charlie - Automobile Parad We see Mary's car drive onto the lot and stop. Mary gets of the car, glances toward the lot office, turns her atte to the line of cars, notice the California licence plates all of them. The CAR DEALER calls out from his office:

With you in a second! Mary nods, starts walking along the line of cars as if ma a selection. Her eye is caught by the iron newspaper stan on the corner, just outside the lot. She stares at the papers, turns away, as if what she is  fearing would have to be impossible, then, having to sati herself, goes to the stand, drops a dime in the iron slot picks up a LOS ANGELES newspaper, starts back into the ca lot as she glances worried at the front page. As she goes we see, coming up the street toward the lot, the same  PATROLMAN. He sees Mary, slows, swerves over to the oppos side of the street, stops by the curb. Mary, engrossed in the newspaper, and walking back ease the lot, does not se the Patrolman. The car dealer is out on the lot now, standing and waitin for Mary. As she approaches, lost in her newspaper, he sm
I'm in no mood for trouble!
(glancing up, thrown  for a moment)
What?
(cheerfully)

There's an old saying, "First customer  of the day is always the most  trouble!" But like I said, I'm in no  mood for it so I'm just going to  treat you so fair and square you  won't have one human reason to give  me...
(interrupting)
Can I trade in my car and take  another?
You can do anything you've a mind  to... and bein' a woman, you will! (chin-indicating her  car)
That yours?
Yes, it's... nothing wrong with it,  I'm just...
Sick of the sight of it! (laughs)
Well, suppose you look around for  something that strikes your eyes and  meanwhile I'll have my mechanic give  yours the once over and... want some  coffee? I was just about...
No. Thank you. I'm in... a hurry. I  just want to make a change and  start... She stops suddenly, almost with a gasp. She has seen the  Patrolman.
He is staring over at her, his face dispassionate.
Mary has to force herself to look away.
One thing people never ought to be  when they're buying a used car is in  a hurry! (starting away toward  her car)

But like I said, too nice a day for  arguing. I'll just shoot this into  the garage. He starts into Mary's car. She looks at him, in near pani wanting to skip the whole thing. Torn, wondering if the  presence of the Patrolman doesn't negate the value of cha cars, wondering how she can get away, wondering if she'll followed, or if the Patrolman will go away if she does st here. All these panic-fears rush her mind and she can do nothin The Car Dealer has driven her car into the garage. She st in the middle of the lot, feeling like a shooting target. She looks toward the garage.
Mary's car is in it.
Mary decides she cannot back out now without arousing fur suspicion, is compelled to look again at the Patrolman.
He still watches. With a self-angry sigh of resignment, s goes to a close car, looks at it. The Car Dealer is retur
That's the one I'd've picked for you  myself!
How much?

Go ahead! Spin it around the block.  Now I know you don't know anything  about engine condition, but you can  feel, can't you... and it's all in  the feel, believe me, you feel that  one around the block...
It looks fine. How much will it be,  with my car...?
You mean you don't want the usual  day and a half to think it over? (laughs)
You are in a hurry! Somebody chasin'  you?
Of course not. Please.
Well... heck, this is the first time  I ever saw the customer high-pressure  the salesman! (laughs, sees she is  in no mood for it)
I'd figure roughly... (looks at the car,  then back at the  garage)
...your car plus five hundred.
Five hundred.
Aha! Always got time to argue money,  huh...?
All right. As the car dealer looks at her in amazement, she reaches  into her bag, feels the money-filled envelope, pauses.
(slowly)
I take it... you can prove that car's  yours... I mean, out of state and  all... got your pink slip and your...
I think I have the necessary papers.  Is there a Ladies Room...
In the building ... (indicates, continues  to stare quietly)
Mary starts for the building, glancing  once in the direction of the  Patrolman.
He still sits, his motor throbbing, his face quiet.
Mary goes into the office building.

Mary enters, locks door, takes envelope out of her handba extracts one bundle of bills from the envelope, counts of five, puts the bundle back into the envelope and the enve back into the bag. Then she remembers, takes out the impo papers envelope, goes through it, finds several papers ha to do with her car, takes them all out, puts back the  envelope, starts out of the ladies Room.
The Car Dealer has moved the car of her choice out of the line. It stands in the clearing.
(too cheerfully)
I think you'd better give it a trial  spin. Don't want any bad word of  mouth about California Charlie.
I'd really rather not. Please.  Can't  we just settle this and...
I'll be perfectly honest with you,  Ma'am. It's not that I don't trust  you, but...
(interrupting)
But what?  Is there anything so  terribly wrong about... making a  decision and wanting to hurry? Do  you think I've stolen... my car?
No, M'am. I was only about to say,  I've sent my mechanic out to give  your car a little test... that's  all.
(handing him the  ownership papers and  the new bills)
I'd like to be ready when he gets  back.
Okay. If you'll come along... He starts toward the office building. Mary follows, close anxiously. She glances, sees:
He is still at the far curb.
The Car Dealer goes into his office. Mary follows.

A second later, he starts his automobile, checks traffic, comes across the street, slowly, and drives onto the lot. pauses a moment, then drives across the lot, passing the  office, going on to the other exit, stops there as Mary's car is driven back onto the lot. The MECHANIC stops Mary's car, hops out, waves to the  Patrolman. The Patrolman waves back, goes on a bit until is behind Mary's car, stops again, looks over at the offi In a moment, Mary comes out, hurries across to her new ca gets in, starts the motor. The Mechanic yells:
Hey! Miss? Mary pauses, turns, sees the Patrolman, then the Mechanic Her face goes white. She doesn't know which man called he Then the Mechanic waves, starts forward with her suitcase
(as Mechanic reaches  car)

Just put it right in here, please...  beside me. The Mechanic smiles, throws the suitcase in. Mary zooms o As she drives out of lot we see the Mechanic, the Car Dea and the Patrolman all looking after her.

head_text.subj: MARY IN NEW CAR ON ROUTE

text: Mary is driving tensely. She checks the rear-view mirror, more shocked than pleased when she sees...
No sign of the Patrolman.

head_text.subj: MARY IN NEW CAR ON ROUTE

text: She turns her face, looks out at the highway.
It is heavy with traffic.

head_text.subj: MARY IN NEW CAR ON ROUTE

text: Again she checks the mirror and although...
There is still no sign of the Patrolman.

head_text.subj: MARY IN NEW CAR ON ROUTE

text: She cannot relax or feel safe, cannot convince herself th nothing will come of the man's watching and suspicions. CAMERA IS CLOSE on Mary's face now, recording her anxiety her fears. Her guilt shines bright in her eyes and she is person unaccustomed to containing this much guilt in this realistic a situation. Suddenly, we hear the SOUND of the Used Car Dealer's laugh, hear it as clearly as Mary hears in her imagination. The "imagined voice" we hear is actua the voice of the Car Dealer:
Heck, Officer, that was the first  time I ever saw the Customer high- pressure the Salesman!  Somebody  chasing her?
I better have a look at those papers,  Charlie.
She look like a wrong-one to you?
Acted like one. Mary blinks, shakes her head, as if trying to shake away  these voices of her imagination. She checks the rear-view mirror.
Still no sight of the Patrolman.
She tries to force herself to relax, almost succeeds when she is sprung to tension again by....
The sight of a police car. As she drives past, we hear th squeaky, unintelligible voice coming over the car radio.  Mary zooms down on the gas, whizzes ahead.
Mary's car dashing along.
Mary looks weary, tired with strain and with hard driving Her eyes are heavy with worry and deep thought.
We can see that it is much later in the day, almost dusk.
We HEAR the sound of an agitated BUZZ of an intercom syst a sound emanating from Mary's imagination. After the second BUZZ, we HEAR the voice of Caroline.
Yes, Mr. Lowery.
(a worried tone)
Caroline...? Mary still isn't in?
No, Mr. Lowery... but then she's  always a bit late on Monday mornings.
Buzz me the minute she comes in. Again Mary shakes her head, forces herself to stop hearin these "invented" scenes of her imagination.
Now we cut to the view of the road, from Mary's viewpoint Darkness of evening is coming. In the dim twilight we see the neon sign of roadside restaurants and gas stations  beginning to blaze on.
Back on Mary's face, and after a moment, the imagined voi again:
Call her sister! If no one's answering  at the house....
I called her sister, Mr. Lowery,  where she works, the Music Makers  Music Store, you know? And she doesn't  know where Mary is any more than we  do.
You better run out to the house.   She may be... unable to answer the  phone...
Her sister's going to do that.  She's  as worried as we are. A flush of painful guilt and regret rises up in Mary's fa She closes her eyes for one tight swift moment.
We cut again to the highway. The first oncoming headlight slash at the windshield.

Cutting back to Mary, we can sense by the tense muscles o her face that she is driving faster. The oncoming headlig blurt at her. Suddenly we HEAR Lowery's voice, loud now and frightened, if the anxiety in the man's voice was strong enough to br through Mary's effort to keep her mind silent and her  imagination blank.

No! I haven't the faintest idea.  As  I said, I last saw your sister when  she left this office on Friday...  she said she didn't feel well and  wanted to leave early and I said she  could. And that was the last I saw... (a pause, a thought)
...wait a minute, I did see her, an  hour or so later, driving... (a pause, then with  solemn fear)
Ah, I think you'd better come over  here to my office. Quick. (a pause, a click)
Caroline, get Mr. Cassidy for me.
It is completely dark now, night.
We cut back to her face.

After all, Cassidy, I told you...   all that cash... I'm not taking the  responsibility... Oh, for heaven's  sake, a girl works for you for ten  years, you trust her! All right,  yes, you better come over.

location: THE ROAD AHEAD INT. MARY'S NEW CAR

text: Fast cut back to Mary's face. Oncoming headlights throw a blinding light across her features.
(undrunk, sharp with  rage)
Well I ain't about to kiss off forty  thousand dollars! I'll get it back  and if any of it's missin' I'll  replace it with her fine soft flesh!  I'll track her, never you doubt it!
Hold on, Cassidy... I still can't  believe... it must be some kind of a  mystery... I can't...

You checked with the bank, no?  They  never laid eyes on her, no?  You  still trustin'? Hot creepers, she  sat there while I dumped it out...  hardly even looked at it, plannin'  and... and even flirtin' with me...! A look of revulsion makes Mary close her eyes.
Big drops of rain begin to appear.
She is becoming aware of the rain starting.
The rain increasing and backlit by the oncoming headlight
Mary starts the windshield wipers.
The wipers are having a battle with the now torrential ra
Peering through the blurred windshield.
slowing down in the flooding highway.
peering through the windshield. The oncoming lights are f
almost coming to a slow turn.
just blackness and rain.
peering.
An almost undiscernible light in the far distance, a neon sign blurred by the rain-sheeted windshield.
She presses down, forces the car to move on through the  flooded road.

As we move closer, we see the neon sign more clearly and faintly make out the large letters which read "Motel."  M stops the car, lowers the window slightly, looks out. We the sign clearly now: "BATES MOTEL." Mary opens the car d and dashes out into the rain and up onto the porch of the motel office.

Mary pauses on the porch. The lights are on within the of She tries door, finds it open, goes into office. CAMERA  FOLLOWS her into office. There is no one present. Mary go to the desk, rings a small pushbell. There is no response Mary rubs her forehead in weariness and frustration, goes back out onto the porch. She looks off in another directi slightly behind the office, and sees...

A path from the motel office leads directly up to this ho There is a light on in one of the upstairs rooms. A WOMAN passes the window, pauses, peers out. We see her in clear silhouette. She quickly goes away fro the window.

Mary, having seen the woman, expects now that she will ge some attention. She stands a few moments, waiting. No one comes. Impatience and anger rise in Mary. She dash out into the rain, to her car, gets in, opens the side wi begins to honk the horn. After a moment, a YOUNG MAN open the front door of the house, pauses, starts down the path After a few steps, he turns and runs back into the house. Mary leaves her car, starts a dash for the shelter of the porch. As she runs, we see that the Young Man has gone ba only to get an umbrella. Seeing that Mary is on her way t the porch, he runs quickly, the umbrella unopened in his  hand. He gets to the porch a moment after Mary has reache it. He stops short, looks at her, then at the umbrella hangin useless in his hand, then back to her. There is something sadly touching in his manner, in his l Mary's impatience goes and she smiles and this makes him  almost smile. He gestures her into the office, standing b to indicate that he will go after her. She goes into the  office.
The Young Man follows Mary in, closes the door. He is NOR BATES, somewhere in his late twenties, thin and tall, sof spoken and hesitant.
Dirty night.
(not really a question)
You have a vacancy?
(simply, almost  cheerfully)
We have twelve vacancies. Twelve  cabins, twelve vacancies. (a pause)
They moved away the highway.
I thought I'd gotten off the main...
I knew you must have. No one stops  here anymore unless they do. He is behind the counter now, pushing forward the registr book.

But it's no good dwelling on our  losses, is it.  We go right ahead  lighting signs and following the  formalities...  Would you sign,  please. Mary has placed her handbag on the counter. She takes the registration book, picks up the pen, is suddenly struck w the realization that she'd better use an alias. She write the name Marie Samuels.
Your home address. Oh, just the town  will do.
(glancing at newspaper  sticking out of her  handbag)
Los Angeles. She realizes he didn't ask her to tell him, merely to wri it down. She smiles, writes Los Angeles beside the false  name. Norman smiles, stops smiling out of embarrassment.
Cabin One. It's closer in case you  want anything... right next to the  office.
He removes a key for Cabin One. We see that there is a  remaining key on the board.
I want sleep more than anything.   Except maybe, food.
There's a big diner about ten miles  on up... just outside Fairvale.
Am I that close to Fairvale?

Fifteen miles. I'll get your bags. He goes to door, opens it. The rain has slowed down  considerably. He smiles at this fact, as if to communicat some pleasure he finds in it. Mary follows him to the doo goes out on the porch, waits and watches as Norman runs t her car, gets in, drives it to the parking space in front Cabin One. Mary walks along the porch, waits before the d of Cabin One. Norman gets out of car, with suitcase, runs to the door,  opens it, pushes the door open, puts his hand in and swit on a light. Mary goes into the cabin. Norman follows her.
Norman places suitcase on bed, goes to the window, opens
Stuffy in here. (turns to her)

Well... the mattress is soft and  there're hangers in the closet and...  stationary with "Bates' Motel" printed  on it in case you want to make your  friends back home envious... and...  the... over there.... (he points to the  bathroom, fairly  blushes)
The bathroom.
(quickly, starting to  leave)
I'll be in the office if you want  anything... just tap on the wall.
Thank you, Mr. Bates.
Norman Bates. He pauses at the door, gazes at her. She smiles.
You have something most girls never  have.
I have?
There's no name for it... But it's  something that, that puts a person  at ease.
Thank you. Again.
(not really a question)
You're not going to go out again and  drive up to that diner, are you?
No.
Then will you do me a favor? (without waiting for  her response)

Will you have supper here?  I was  just about to, myself... nothing  more than some sandwiches and a lot  of milk, but I'd like it if you'd  come up to the house and... I don't  set a fancy table but... the kitchen's  awful homey.
I'd like to.
All right, you get your dresses  hanging out and... change those wet  shoes, and I'll come for you soon as  it's ready... (starts out)
...with my trusty umbrella. (he laughs a small  laugh, runs off)

Mary closes the door, goes to suitcase, opens it, starts take out a dress. Her handbag is next to the suitcase. Sh glances down into it, pauses, drops the dress, reaches in the handbag, takes out the money-filled envelope, stares it, almost with regret, filled contemplates hiding it, de to, starts looking for a reasonable hiding place. She loo about, at the closet, the drawers etc., realizes all such places are obvious. Catching sight of the newspaper in he bag, she hits on a solution. She opens the newspaper, pla the envelope within it, lock-folds the paper again and th places it on the bedside table as if it were there for la reading. She considers this for a moment, accepts it, goe to her suitcase to start unpacking. Suddenly the quiet is shattered by the shrill, ugly sound a woman's voice, raised in anger.

No! I tell you no! Mary walks slowly to the window, realizing that the terri voice is coming from the house behind the cabins. CAMERA  FOLLOWS her to window and once there we see the light is  still on in the upstairs bedroom and the voice is coming  from that room. The rain has stopped and the moon is out.
I won't have you bringing strange  young girls in for supper... (an ugly, sneering  note creeps into the  voice)
...by candlelight, I suppose, in the  cheap erotic fashion of young men  with cheap, erotic minds!
Mother, please...
And then what? After supper, music?  Whispers?
Mother, she's just a stranger...   hungry, and the weather's bad...
(mimicking cruelly)
Mother, she's just a stranger! (hard, cruel again)
As if men don't desire strangers, as  if... oh, I refuse to speak of  disgusting things because they disgust  me! You understand, Boy?
(pause)
Go on, go tell her she'll not be  appeasing her ugly appetite with my  food... or my son! Or do I have to  tell her, cause you don't have the  guts? Huh, boy? You have the guts,  boy?
(blurted cut fury and  shame)

Shut up! Shut up! There is the SOUND of a door closing in that room up ther Mary has stood by the window, listening with mounting dis and concern and sympathy. She turns her face away now, ga sadly at the little empty room. In a moment there is the SOUND of the house's front door  slamming shut. Mary turns, looks out the window.
We see Norman coming down the path, carrying a napkin-cov tray.
Mary looks at him for a moment, then turns quickly, goes the door, opens it and goes out onto the porch.

Mary pauses outside the door, is about to start forward w Norman comes round the building and walks along the porch past the office, stopping only when he is close to her. H stares with painful embarrassment at the knowing look in eye.
I've caused you some trouble.
Mother... (a hollow little laugh,  an attempt at sardonic  humor)
...what is the phrase... "she isn't  herself today"... I think that's it.
(looking at the tray)
You shouldn't have bothered. I really  don't have that much of an appetite. Norman flinches, realizing she has heard his mother's  reference to Mary's appetite.
I'm sorry. I wish... people could  apologize for other people.
Don't worry about it. (a warm smile)

But as long as you've made us supper,  we may as well eat it. Huh? She begins to back into her room. Norman starts to follow hesitates as he sees the total picture of an attractive y woman and a motel room. Bringing down the tray of food, i defiance of his mother's orders, is about the limit of hi defiance for one day. He cannot go into Mary's room.
It might be nicer... warmer in the  office. Without waiting for approval or disapproval, he turns, hu to the office. Mary looks after him, her face showing amu sympathy, then follows.
Norman looks about, tray in hand, sees there is no reason place to spread out a supper. He turns, sees Mary standin in the doorway.
Eating in an office... (a rueful smile)
...to officious, even for me. I have  the parlor behind this... if you'd  like. Mary nods. Norman walks on, behind the counter and into t darkened parlor. Mary follows.

In the darkened room, lit only by the light from the offi spilling in, we see Norman placing the tray on a table. M comes to the doorway, pauses. Norman straightens up, goes lamp, turns on the light. Mary is startled by the room. Even in the dimness of one  lamp, the strange, extraordinary nature of the room rushe up at one. It is a room of birds. Stuffed birds, all over the room, on every available surface, one even clinging t the old fashioned fringed shade of the lamp. The birds ar of many varieties, beautiful, grand, horrible, preying. M stares in awe and a certain fascinated horror.

Please sit down. On the sofa. As Norman goes about spreading out the bread and ham and  pouring the milk, we follow Mary across the room. She stu the birds as she walks, briefly examines a bookcase stack with books on the subject of "Taxidermy."
She notices, too, the paintings on the wall; nudes, prima and many with a vaguely religious overtone. Finally Mary reaches the sofa, sits down, looks at the sp
You're very... kind.

It's all for you. I'm not hungry.   Please go ahead. Mary begins to eat, her attitude a bit tense. She takes u small slice of ham, bites off a tiny bite, nibbles at it the manner of one disturbed and preoccupied. Norman gazes at her, at the tiny bite she has taken, smil and then laughs.
You eat like a bird.
You'd know, of course.
Not really. I hear that expression,  that one eats "like a bird," is really  a falsie, I mean a falsity, because  birds eat a tremendous lot. (A pause, then  explaining)

Oh, I don't know anything about birds.  My hobby is stuffing things...  taxidermy. And I guess I'd just rather  stuff birds because...  well, I hate  the look of beasts when they're  stuffed, foxes and chimps and all...  some people even stuff dogs and  cats... but I can't... I think only  birds look well stuffed because  they're rather...  passive, to begin  with... most of them... He trails off, his exuberance failing in the rushing retu of his natural hesitancy and discomfort. Mary looks at hi with some compression, smiles.
It's a strange hobby. Curious, I  mean.
Uncommon, too.
I imagine so.
It's not as expensive as you'd think.  Cheap, really. Needles, thread,  sawdust .. the chemicals are all  that cost anything. (He goes quiet, looks  disturbed)
A man should have a hobby.
It's more than a hobby... sometimes...  a hobby is supposed to pass the time,  not fill it.
(after a pause, softly)
Is your time so empty?
Oh, no! (forcing brightness  again)
I run the office, tend the cabins  and grounds, do little chores for  mother... the ones she allows I might  be capable of doing.
You go out... with friends?
Friends? Who needs friends. (Laughs, then with  gallows humor)
A boy's best friend is his mother. (Stops laughing)
You've never had an empty moment in  your whole life. Have you?
Only my share.
Where are you going? I don't mean to  pry...
(A wistful smile)
I'm looking for a private island.
What are you running away from?
(Alert)
Why do you ask that?
No. People never run away from  anything. (A pause)
The rain didn't last very long. (Turning suddenly)

You know what I think? I think we're  all in our private traps, clamped in  them, and none of us can ever climb  out. We scratch and claw... but only  at the air, only at each other, and  for all of it, we never budge an  inch.
Sometimes we deliberately step into  those traps.
I was born in mine. I don't mind it  anymore.
You should... mind it.
Oh I do... but I say I don't. (Laughs boyishly)
(Staring at him,  shaking her head  softly.)
If anyone ever spoke to me, the way  I heard... The way she spoke to you,  I don't think I could ever laugh  again.
(Controlled resentment)
Sometimes when she talks that way to  me I'd like to... curse her out and  leave her forever! (A rueful smile)
Or at least, defy her. (A pause, a hopeless  shrug)
But I couldn't. She's ill.
She sounded strong...
I mean... ill. (A pause)

She had to raise me all by herself  after my dad died... I was only  five... and it must have been a  strain. Oh, she didn't have to go  out to work or anything, Dad left us  with a little something... anyway, a  few years ago... Mother met a man.  He talked her into building this  motel... We could have talked her  into anything... and when.  Well...  It was just too much for her when he  died, too... And the way he died...  Oh, it's nothing to talk about when  you're eating. (Pauses, smiles)
Anyway, it was too much of a loss  for my mother... she had nothing  left.
(Critically)
Except you.
A son is a poor substitute for a  lover. (Turns away as if in  distaste of the word)
Why don't you go away?
To a private island, like you?
No, not like me.

It's too late for me. And besides...  who'd look after her? She'd be alone  up there, the fire would go out...  damp and cold, like a grave. When  you love someone, you don't do that  to them, even if you hate them. Oh,  I don't hate her.  I hate... what  she's become. I hate... the illness.
(Slowly, carefully)
Wouldn't it be better if you put her  in... someplace... She hesitates. Norman turns, slowly, looking at her with striking coldness.
An Institution? A madhouse?  People  always call a madhouse "someplace." (Mimicing coldly)
Put her in Someplace!
I'm sorry... I didn't mean it to  sound uncaring...
(The coldness turning  to tight fury)

What do you mean about caring?  Have  you ever seen one of those places?  Inside? Laughing and tears and cruel  eyes studying you... and my mother  there?  Why? has she harmed you?   She's as harmless as... one of these  stuffed birds.
I am sorry. I only felt... it seemed  she was harming you. I meant...
(High fury now)

Well? You meant well?  People always  mean well, they cluck their thick  tongues and shake their heads and  suggest so very delicately that... The fury suddenly dies, abruptly and completely, and he s back into his chair. There is a brief silence. Mary watches the troubled man, is almost physically paine by his anguish.
(Quietly)
I've suggested it myself. But I hate  to even think such a thing.  She  needs me... and it isn't... (Looks up with a  childlike pleading  in his eyes)
...it isn't as if she were a maniac,  a raving thing... it's just that...  sometimes she goes a little mad. We  all go a little mad sometimes. Haven't  you?
(After a long  thoughtful pause)
Yes, and just one time can be enough. (Rises)
Thank you.
(Cheerfully, correcting)
Thank you, Norman.
Norman.
You're not going to... to your room  already?
I'm very tired. And I'll have a long  drive tomorrow. All the way back to  Phoenix.
Phoenix?
I stepped into a private trap back  there -- and I want to go back and...  try to pull myself out. (Looking close at  Norman)
Before it's too late for me, too.
(Looking at her)
Why don't you stay a little while,  just for talking.
I'd like to, but...
Alright. I'll see you in the morning.  I'll bring you breakfast.  What time  will you...
Very early. Dawn.
Alright, Miss... (He has forgotten her  name)
Crane.
That's it. (He frowns, as if  bothered by not being  able to match the  name to the memory  of the name in the  registration book)

Good night. She goes out of the parlor. We see her, from Norman's  viewpoint, as she crosses the small office, goes out into the night. Norman turns and looks at the table, and we se his face now. It is bright with that drunken-like look of determination and encouragement and like resolve. He star to clean up the table, pauses as he hears the closing of  Mary's door in the cabin next door. He holds still, listens. He goes into the office and look at the book.

He goes back into the parlor with a mystified expression. The sound of Mary moving about her room come over, soft  SOUNDS, somehow intimate in the night quiet. Norman turns his ear from the direction of the SOUNDS, seems to be fig an impulse to listen, or more than listen. But slowly, he is forced to surrender to the impulse and, resisting himself, he goes to the wall, presses the side his head against it. The SOUNDS come louder, as if we too had our ear pressed against the wall. Now Norman looks at picture hanging on the far end of the wall he is leaning  against. Slowly he starts toward it. He reaches it, touches it, reluctantly lifts the small fr off the wall. A tiny circle of light hits Norman's face, coming from th hole in the wall behind the picture. This end of the room very dim and thus we are able to see clearly the light  striking Norman's face. We move close to Norman, extremely close, until his profi fills the screen. The tiny spot of light hits his eye. Se the small hole through which the light comes. Norman peep through.
Through the hole we look into Mary's cabin, see Mary  undressing. She is in her bra and halfslip. She stoops ov a bit, places her hands behind her upper back, begins to  unhook her bra.
He watches as Mary removes her bra. We see his eye run up and down the unseen figure of Mary.
Mary, just slipping into a robe, covering her complete nu
He turns from the hole, faces us for a moment, continues  turning until he can look out the small parlor window. We see, as he sees...

He turns his face away, quickly, resentfully. In his face see anger and anguish. And then resolve. Quickly, precisely, he rehangs the picture over the hole the wall, turns, starts out of the parlor. We see him go  through the office and out onto the porch, not even bothe to close the door behind him.

Norman walking along the porch, in the direction of the b house. Once on the path he pauses, looks up at the light the bedroom window, then pulls himself up, squares his  shoulders, strides manfully up the path. CAMERA follows behind him. He opens the door of the house enters. We see him pause at the foot of the stairway, loo up at the bedroom door just at the head of the stair. He  holds for a moment, and then his resolve and courage  evaporates. His shoulders slump, sadly, mournfully. He by passes the stairs and slowly makes his way to the kitchen At the far end of the hall. He enters the kitchen, drops  wearily into a chair. After a moment, he stretches out a and gently pushes the kitchen door closed.

Mary is seated at the small desk, engrossed in figuring i small notebook. We see from these figures a calculation w indicates her intention to make a restitution of the mone she has used of the forty thousand dollars. We see, too, bankbook. The paper reads thus: top figure, 40,000; direc beneath it 500, the amount used for the new car; total af subtraction, 39,500. In another spot we see a figure whic matches the balance in her bankbook; 624.00. Beneath this is the figure 500, and the amount after  subtraction, 124.00. She studies the figures, sighs, not  wearily but with a certain satisfaction, with the pleasur that comes when one knows that at any cost one is going t continue doing the right thing. After a moment she tears page out of the notebook and, rising, begins to rip it in small pieces. She goes into the bathroom, drops the piece into the toilet bowl, flushes the toilet. Then she drops robe and steps into the tub and turns the shower on.

Over the bar on which hangs the shower curtain, we can se the bathroom door, not entirely closed. For a moment we w Mary as she washes and soaps herself. There is still a small worry in her eyes, but generally s looks somewhat relieved. Now we see the bathroom door being pushed slowly open. The noise of the shower drowns out any sound. The door is then slowly and carefully closed. And we see the shadow of a woman fall across the shower  curtain. Mary's back is turned to the curtain. The white  brightness of the bathroom is almost blinding. Suddenly we see the hand reach up, grasp the shower curta rip it aside.

As she turns in response to the feel and SOUND of the sho curtain being torn aside. A look of pure horror erupts in her face. A low terrible groan begins to rise up out of h throat. A hand comes into the shot. The hand holds an eno bread knife. The flint of the blade shatters the screen t an almost total, silver blankness.
An impression of a knife slashing, as if tearing at the v screen, ripping the film. Over it the brief gulps of  screaming. And then silence. And then the dreadful thump Mary's body falls in the tub.

The blank whiteness, the blur of the shower water, the ha pulling the shower curtain back. We catch one flicker of glimpse of the murderer. A woman, her face contorted with madness, her head wild with hair, as if she were wearing fright-wig.  And then we see only the curtain, closed acr the tub, and hear the rush of the shower water. Above the shower-bar we see the bathroom door open again and after moment we HEAR the SOUND of the front door slamming.

Lying half in, half out of the tub, the head tumbled over touching the floor, the hair wet, one eye wide open as if popped, one arm lying limp and wet along the tile floor. Coming down the side of the tub, running thick and dark a the porcelain, we see many small threads of blood. CAMERA FOLLOWS away from the body, travels slowly across the  bathroom, past the toilet, out into the bedroom. As CAMER approaches the bed, we see the folded newspaper as Mary p it on the bedside table.
beside the bed. The CAMERA now moves away over to the win and looks up to the house, and as it gets there we HEAR,  coming from within the house, the SOUND of Norman's fearf shocked voice.

Mother! Oh God, what... blood,  blood... mother...! We cannot entirely distinguish these exclamations. After a moment or two of silence, Norman emerges from the front door, dashes down the path toward the motel.

Norman is coming AT CAMERA, running head-on. He dashes in an extreme close up and we see the terror and fear ripe i his face. CAMERA PANS as Norman races past, holds as Norm runs to the porch and quickly along it and directly to Ma room.

Norman pauses a moment in the doorway, glances about the  room, hears the shower going, sees the bathroom door is o He goes to the bathroom, looks in, sees the body. Slowly, almost carefully, he raises his hands to his face covers his eyes, turns his face away. Then he crosses to window, looks out at the house. Shot is so angled that we see the bedside table with the newspaper on it. After a moment, Norman moves from the window, sinks onto edge of the bed.

Norman sitting on bed, the bathroom in b.g. of shot. We c see only the hand of the dead girl, lying along the tile  floor. Norman presses his eyes, fights to find a way out his dilemma. Slowly, a kind of settling comes upon him, t peace that comes with decision. Norman rises, goes to the window, looks out, and then, wi resolution, closes the window and draws the curtain acros it. Then he crosses to the front window, facing the porch and draws those curtains closed. Then he switches off the bedroom light, leaving the room lit only by the spill fro the bathroom. He opens the front door, goes out.

Norman comes out of Mary's cabin, closes the door careful behind him, goes along the porch to his office, goes in. stay outside. Immediately, the "Vacancy" sign goes off, a then the motel sign goes off. As CAMERA GOES closer to th office, the lights within go off and we HEAR a closet doo opening and then the SOUND of a pail being picked up. Nor comes out of office, closes door, looks cautiously about, goes along porch, carrying pail with mop in it, goes into Mary's cabin, closing the door after him.

With the paper in the foreground, Norman enters. We can s him in the dim spill of light. He pauses by the door, the gathers his strength and goes into the bathroom. We HEAR set the pail on the tiled floor, and then we HEAR the sho being turned off. And there is total silence. CAMERA MOVE FORWARD so that we can see into bathroom. CAMERA is ANGLED that we see Norman only from the waist u Quickly and deftly he unhooks the shower curtain, emerges with it into the bedroom. CAMERA PANS down and we see him spread the shower curtain on the bedroom floor, just outs the bathroom door. He spreads the curtain so that one end it comes up against the bathroom threshold and slightly o and onto the tile floor. Again he goes into the bathroom CAMERA TILTS up so that we see only the upper half of Nor He works carefully, with his arms extended away from his  body, slowly pulls the dead body out of the tub, drags it across the tile floor and onto the spread-out shower curt in the bedroom. Having arranged the body, he straightens examines his hands, sees bloodstains on them. He returns the bathroom, goes to the hand-basin.
We see his hands being washed, see the bloodstains being  diluted and washed away by the gush of the faucet water.

We see Norman shake his hands free of the water, then tur to the job of cleaning the bathroom. He places the pail in the tub, runs water into it, dips t mop in, swabs the tile floor. With a towel he wipes off t wall over the tub and the edges and sides of the tub and  even the shower curtain rod. Then he takes a second towel and goes over the cleaned areas, carefully drying them.   Finally he rinses and squeezes out the mop, empties the p cleans out the tub, and goes out into the bedroom.

Norman steps carefully around the unseen body, crosses to the desk, starts going through Mary's handbag, in search her car keys. He suddenly notices them lying on the desk, where he'd thrown them after parking her car. He picks up the keys, crosses the room, goes out.

We see Norman pauses at the door, check cautiously, then  hurry across the porch and into Mary's car. He circle-tur the car, so that its trunk is backed up to the turns porc directly opposite Mary's door, as close as it can go. Then he alights, goes to the trunk, opens it with the key and, leaving the trunk lid raised, goes back into the cab

From a raised angle, we see Norman bend down and begin to wrap the shower curtain around the body. We see the edges the curtain as they are raised and laid down again. Then picks up the wrapped body, crosses to the door, uses his  foot to pull the door open, and, leaving the door open be him, goes quickly across the porch and gently lays the bo in the trunk. He closes the lid then, but does not lock i He comes back into the cabin, closes the door completely, flicks on the light. Again the newspaper is in the foreground. For a moment he pauses, closes his eyes against the realization of what h is doing, then quickly pushes all thoughts away, continue with his work. With the room lighted, he now proceeds to  gather up all Mary's articles and toss them into the suit He checks all drawers and the closet, gets down and check under bed and bureau, goes into the bathroom, checks that room again, comes back into the bedroom, looks about  carefully, spots Mary's handbag, throws even that into th suitcase, is finally satisfied that all traces of the gir are gone from the room. Then he closes Mary's suitcase, p it up. With his free hand he picks up the pail, in which are the mop and the used towels. He crosses to the door, switches off the light with his shoulder, pulls open the door, sta out.

As Norman stands in the doorway, he is suddenly and blind lit by the bright headlights of a passing car. The flash the lights and the SOUND of the SPEEDING CAR are over in flicker of a moment, but it takes a few seconds for Norma to regain his former tense composure. Then he goes to the car trunk, raises it with his foot, throws the suitcase a the pail into it, slams it shut. He pauses a moment, then realizes he has left the bathroom light on in Mary's cabi He returns to cabin. As he enters, his eye is caught by t newspaper on the bedside table. He goes to it, takes the  newspaper, and looks once again into the bathroom. His gl goes right over the toilet bowl. He turns out the lights, crosses the darkened cabin, goes out onto the porch. He reopens the trunk, tosses in the newspaper and closes He goes around and jumps into the car and starts away. We HOLD on the trunk, follow it for a while, then

The car pulls away from a CLOSE ANGLE on the trunk and as CAMERA HOLDS we see that we are now in a swamp area. It is quiet except for the irritating noises of night ins Norman stops the car at the very edge of the swamp, turns off the lights, gets out, leaving door open. He looks at swamp, seems doubtful of its ability to swallow up the ca realizes he has no choice. He leans into the car, release the emergency brake, starts to push. The front of the car begins to roll into the swamp. Suddenly there is the LOW, THROBBING SOUND of a motor. Norman freezes, listens. The SOUND grows louder and Norman realizes it is an airpl flying overhead. The car is rolling quickly now. Norman j away, slams the door shut, stands tense. The SOUND of the plane overhead grows louder. Norman looks up.
We see no plane. The SOUND of the motor is beginning to  diminish.

We see the relief in his face. He looks at the car. More than two-thirds of it have already sunk into the swa The trunk alone seems to hold poised above the sand and s as if refusing to go the rest of the way. Norman begins t panic, he steps dangerously close, pushes with his foot. slowly the car sinks, until finally it is gone and we hea only the gentle plop of the swamp's final gulp, and see o the small after-bubble, like a visual burp. Norman waits a moment, then begins stamping out the tire  marks, so obvious in the wet ground around the swamp. He stamps and drags his feet over the markings as we:

standing on the porch of the motel, leaning against a pos He is staring out into the night, a look of guarded, casu innocence on his face, as if he were taking one last mome of peaceful night air before retiring. Then he glances do and CAMERA follows his gaze. A hose is lying on the groun outside Mary's cabin, its stream of water obliterating th tire marks. After a moment, Norman's hand comes into shot, picks up h places it in a new position. As CAMERA PULLS BACK, we see that the water from the hose has erased and rearranged th road markings so that it would be impossible to tell that car had been parked here. After a short wait, Norman goes to the hose-faucet, turns off, unscrews the hose. As he rolls the hose, he walks aw from the spot, past the office, heading for the path that leads to the house. He goes up the path, pauses at the st of the house, tosses the curled hose onto the lawn, goes the steps and into the house. CAMERA FOLLOWS him in, PAUS as he pauses at the foot of the stairs. Norman goes up th stairs. On the landing he stops. The door to his mother's room is closed. Lying in a heap outside the door are a blood-stai dress and a pair of elderly-woman's shoes. From an EXTREM HIGH ANGLE, we look down on Norman as he bends to pick up the stained dress and shoes. He rolls the shoes into the dress, tucks the small, neat  bundle under his arm, and starts down the stairs, heading for the basement.
It stands silhouetted against the sky. There is a long wa Then, slowly, a curl of smoke comes out of the chimney.

location: BACK ROOM OF SAM'S HARDWARE STORE IN FAIRVALE

text: Sam is seated at his desk, writing a letter. Sequence begins with CAMERA IN CLOSE, over Sam's shoulder, and we read as mush as he has written of the letter. The letterh reads "Sam Loomis - Hardware," and the letter reads: "Dea right-as-always Mary: I'm sitting in this tiny back room  which isn't big enough for both of us, and suddenly it lo big enough for both of us. So what if we're poor and cram and miserable, at least we'll be happy! If you haven't co to your senses, and still want to... CAMERA begins PULLING AWAY as Sam turns the sheet of pape over, continues backing away out of the small back room a heads, backwards, down the corridor, we see a young clerk BOB SUMMERFIELD, Sam's assistant, standing behind the cou a look of handsome patience on his face. He is waiting on meticulous, elderly woman customer, who is holding and  examining a large can of insecticide. As CAMERA PASSES:

...They tell you what its ingredients  are and how it's guaranteed to  exterminate any insect in the world,  but they do not tell you whether or  not it's painless. And I say insect  or man, death should always be  painless. CAMERA, by this has reached the front door of the hardwar store and we now see a girl standing just inside the door She is an attractive girl with a rather definite manner, look of purposefulness. She carries a handbag and a small overnight case. She is Mary's sister, LILA CRANE. Bob Summerfield has noticed Lila, smiles brightly at her, gives her an I'll-be-with-you-in-a-moment nod. Lila starts to walk toward the counter, never taking her  eyes off Bob. As she approaches, she asks quietly:
Sam?
You want to see Sam?
Sam Loomis.
(yelling toward back  room)

Sam! Lady wants to see you! Lila looks to the back room. The woman customer goes on  worriedly examining the fine print of the insecticide can Sam comes to the door of his room, pauses, looks at Lila moment, starts toward her, his expression indicating that does not know her. Lila studies him with a quiet, worried expression.
Yes?
May I talk to you?
(a bit mystified)

Sure... Lila glances at the customer and the clerk, turns, starts toward the front of the store. Sam holds a moment, then  follows. As he reaches her, she turns, her eyes studying intently as she says:
I'm Mary's sister.
Lila.
(quickly)
Is Mary here? Sam is mystified, and is also aware of the worried, hosti expression on Lila's face. He studies her for a quiet mom Behind them is a display of various size carving knives.
Is something wrong?
I want to know if my sister is here.
Here?
With you.
Where?
I don't know where. In your store,  somewhere in your town... anywhere.
What's the matter?
Don't you know? As Sam is about to speak, the Woman Customer comes sailin past, speaking as she goes and wearing a satisfied smile.
All I can do is hope if it isn't  painless, it's quick! She speaks "quick" with a kind of delicious bite, nods  happily, goes on out of the store. Sam is now staring  apprehensively at Lila.
What should I know?
To begin with, where Mary is. Do  you?
No. I take it you don't either? (As Lila shakes her  head)
How long?
Last Friday. She left work, and  home... I was in Tucson over the  weekend... I haven't heard from her,  not even a phone call.
And you thought she'd come up here,  to me? If she had, what reason would  she have for not calling you?
A good reason, I suppose.
(Slightly exasperated)
Well what do you think, we eloped or  something? Or we're living in sin  and...
Mr. Loomis, you're so busy being  defensive that you haven't even  reacted to the most serious fact of  all. Mary is missing.
I was getting to that!
What do you know about it?
Nothing! You're putting me on the  defensive.

Look, if you two are in this thing  together, I don't care, it's none of  my business... But I want to see  Mary. I want her to tell me she's  all right and it's none of my  business. Then I'll go back to Phoenix  and... She stops, the anxiety and fear building up in her, her e beginning to fill with worried tears. Sam studies her for moment, then turns and calls:
Bob? Run out and get yourself some  lunch.
It's okay, Sam, I brought it with  me.
Run out and eat it. Bob gets the message, goes out through the back way. Sam goes closer to Lila, speaks with soft seriousness.
What thing?
Huh?
What thing could we be in together?
(A pause)
I hate tears. (Takes out hankie)
Is Mary... in trouble?
Yes.
Well why didn't she come to me...   call me...?
Not that kind... (Almost a smile)
You men and your egos.
(Seriously)

Never mind my ego. Let's talk about  Mary. Their attention is distracted by a man who has strolled  quietly into the room. He ignores them, walks past them,  goes behind the counter, takes down a sign reading "CLOSE FOR LUNCH," walks back to the door, closes door, hangs th sign across the door window, locks the door, turns to Sam and Lila, folds his arms, smiles a particularly unfriendl smile.
Let's all talk about Mary.
Who are you, friend?
Milt Arbogast, Private Investigator. (To Lila)
Where is she, Miss Crane?
I don't know.
Wouldn't have been able to tail you  if you did.
What's your interest?
Money. There is a moment's silence and then, unable to tolerate sudden frightening happenings, Sam explodes.
Somebody better tell me what's going  on and tell me fast! I can take so  much and then...
(Interrupting calmly)
Your girl friend stole forty thousand  dollars. Sam looks at Arbogast in utter shock and in that state as one of those seemingly ridiculous questions.
Why?
(An almost amused  smile)
Must've needed it.
What are you talking about? (To Lila)
What is this?
She was supposed to bank it, on  Friday, for her boss. She didn't. And no one has seen her since.
(Looking at Sam)
Someone has seen her. Someone always  sees a girl with forty thousand  dollars. (To Sam)
She is your girl friend, isn't she?
Sam, they don't want to prosecute,  they just want the money back. It  was all in cash...
(Correcting with  Cassidy's word)
Casharoonie!
Sam, if she's here...
She isn't! A real look of anguish comes into Lila's face. And Arboga studies it, then speaks.
You came up here on a hunch, Miss  Crane? Nothing more? No phone call...  from him, or from your sister herself?
(wearily)
Not even a hunch. Just hope.
With a little checking, I could get  to believe you.
(anxiously)
I don't care if you do or... I want  to see Mary... before she gets in  any deeper...
Did you check in Phoenix...  hospitals... maybe she had an  accident... a hold-up...
She was seen leaving town in her  car. Seen by her very victims, I  might add.
(after a moment)
I don't believe it. (to Lila, slowly)
Do you?
(a thoughtful pause)
Yes... I just... did. The moment  they told me...
You might have doubted for say five  minutes or so, Sister. Lila turns from Sam, a flush of guilt and regret in her f Arbogast looks at her, quiet sympathetically.
We're always quickest to doubt people  who have a record for being honest.   I think she's here, Miss Crane. Where  there's a boyfriend... (Trails off, smiles  encouragingly)

She won't be back there among the  nuts and bolts... but she'll be in  this town... somewhere. I'll find  her. He nods, takes down the closed-for-lunch sign, sails it t the counter, opens door, goes out into the street. After a quiet moment:
I just listened... and believed  everything they told me. 'She stole  the money.' 'We don't want to get  her in trouble.' 'No don't bring the  police in'...
It was her boss' idea not to report  it to the police?
No. The man whose money she... he  talked so loud and fast, and I... I  should've called the police.
He must have had a darn good reason  for wanting them kept out of it...   All that cash...
I ought to call the police right  now!
No.
Why not? Sam, is she hiding here?   Are you two planning to go away with  the money?
How could I go away? I'm in debt up  to my... (Smiles at the  incongruity of his  reply, then goes  serious)
If she did steal that money...  It's  hard to believe she did because it's  hard to see why she would. Unless  she had some wild idea that it would  help me... us...
She haven't even called you?
I didn't see her... and I didn't  hear from her! Believe that!
I need to... I need to believe  something. This is the first time  I've ever come up against anything I  couldn't... understand.
You've led a charmed life.
No. I just think... anything can be  explained. But Mary, doing a thing  like this... I don't know how to  handle...
Maybe we can handle it together. (He smiles  encouragingly)
(A rueful shrug)
I came flying up here expecting to  get some explanation... for all I  know, she may be trying to get in  touch with me, at home. I'd better  go home.
(A thoughtful pause)
I think she'll contact me if she  contacts anybody. Why don't you stay  here. When she shows up... or calls...  be here.
(A long study, her  suspicion of him  evaporating)
You want me to stay here?
She'll need both of us.
(considers, then:)
Where... can I stay?
(brightly)
First rate hotel, fifty yards up the  street. Come on. (as he reaches for  the closed-for-lunch  sign)
After we check you in we'll go to  the drugstore and get you a sandwich.  Then we'll come back here... and  wait. He hangs the sign on the door, ushers Lila out, closes do behind him.
They emerge from the store and walk along to the hotel. they enter, Arbogast is in the act of taking over a white Ford sedan from a rental car man. They glance at him and returns a cynical look.
Outside another hotel we see Arbogast alight from the whi car and go into new hotel.
The white car speeding along the highway.
Arbogast going into the office - we see the sign above hi
A high shot showing the freeway and Bates house and motel the side old highway. A pause and then across the bottom the picture a white car speeds by on the freeway.
Another Hotel. Arbogast goes in.
The white car speeding along the freeway again going in t opposite direction to last time. Norman, a tiny figure, i seen going up the steps to his mother's house.
Arbogast's search is getting down in the scale. This is a entrance to a cheesy boarding house. "Rooms to Rent," etc He looks at his list and then goes in.
The white car goes by on the freeway again.
Arbogast goes in.

Heavy traffic on the freeway. A beat or two - again the w car. It slows up opposite the distant motel. It makes a t and goes back out of scene. A pause and it reappears on t old road and slowly makes its way toward the Bates' Motel

We now see Norman. He has brought out an old rocking chai and has placed it on the office porch and is sitting hunc in it. And he is darning one of his own socks. CAMERA HOL Beyond the porch, and Norman, we see the old house and ca barely make out, in the twilight dimness, the figure of h mother seated at the window. Here, too, there is that qua of quiet peace surrounded by a vague foreboding. Now Norman looks up at the SOUND of the approaching car. And continues looking as the car comes to a stop and Arbo gets out. Arbogast gives the place a quick once-over, gaz at Norman, starts forward. In his steps and manner there that bored, routine-logged quality of a man who has seen many motels and asked question of too many hotel managers over too short a period of time. Norman rises as Arbogast comes forward.
(shoving sock in his  pocket)
I always forget to put the sign on,  but we do have vacancy. (Cheerfully)
Twelve in fact. Twelve cabins, twelve  vacancies.
(pleasantly)
In the past two days I've been to so  many motels, my eyes are bleary with  neon. This is the first one that  looked like it was hiding from the  world at large.
I don't really forget the sign, it  just doesn't seem... any use. (Points)
This used to be the main highway. (Starts for office)
Want to register, please?
Sit down. I don't want to trouble  you, just want to ask...
No trouble. Today's linen day. I  change all the beds once a week,  whether they've been used or not...  dampness. I hate the smell of  dampness. (Opening office door)
It's such a dank smell. Norman is holding the door open, so Arbogast walks in. Norman follows.
Norman switches on the overhead light, starts for the lin closet, suddenly pauses, turns, studies Arbogast, who has remained standing by the door.
You out to buy a motel?
No.
Oh. I thought... you said you'd been  to so many in two days...  What was  it you wanted to ask?
