I'm looking for a missing person. (takes out and opens  wallet and extends  it as he speaks)
My name's Arbogast, private  investigator... (takes back wallet  when Norman doesn't  look at it)
Trying to trace a young girl who's  been missing almost a week. From  Phoenix. (A look at Norman's  frightened expression)
It's a private matter... family wants  to forgive her... (smiles)
She isn't in trouble.
(forcing a smile)
I didn't think the police went  searching for people who weren't in  trouble.
I'm not the police.
Oh. He waits a moment, then opens closet, starts counting out sheets and pillow cases, keeps his back to Arbogast. Arbogast takes a photograph out of his pocket, talks as h crosses to Norman.
We have reason to believe she came  this way... might have stopped in  this area... (extends photograph,  which Norman doesn't  glance at)
Did she stop here?
No. No one has stopped here in  weeks...
Mind looking at the picture before  committing yourself?
Committing myself to what? You sure  talk like a Policeman.
Look at the picture. Please. Norman glances, briefly, turns away, lifts sheets and pil cases off the shelf holds them close, almost protectively
No. At least I don't recall.
She might have used an alias. Mary  Crane's the real name, but she  might've registered...
(interrupting)
I don't even bother with guests  registering any more... I mean, little  by little, you drop the formalities. (more relaxed, because  Arbogast is listening  with a pleasant smile)
I shouldn't even bother to change  the linen. I guess habits die hard.  Which reminds me... He goes to the wall, flips a light switch.
The vacancy sign. Just in case. We had a couple the other night, said if the sign hasn't  been on they'd have thought this was an old deserted mini town or something.
Now there's a couple even remarking  about your sign, and see how easily  you forgot them?
What?
You thought no one has stopped here  in weeks. Now, try to remember if  this girl...
(A pause, a study)

Maybe she even signed the register...  because habits die hard. Let's check  it, huh? Norman says nothing. Arbogast goes to the desk, pulls the registry book around, flips back a page or two. Norman simply stares at the man. Arbogast hums faintly,  pleasantly, as he examines the pages. Then:

Yes sir! Marie Samuels.  Interesting  alias. He takes a slip of paper out of his pocket, lays it besid the signature in the registry book, all the while nodding and smiling nicely, as if this discovery will make Norman happy as it is making him.
Don't know where she got "Marie,"  but "Samuels" figures. Her boy  friend's name is Sam. (Turns to Norman, the  smile gone)
Was she in disguise? Or do you want  to check the picture again?
I didn't lie to you. I just have  trouble keeping track of... time. Arbogast has reached him, the picture extended. Norman lo dutifully at it.
It was raining and her hair didn't  look like that... damped out, I guess.
Tell me all about her.
She arrived kind of late, wet and  hungry and she was very tired and  went right to bed and left early.
How early?
Very early. Dawn.
Of which morning?
The following morning. Sunday.
No one met her?
No.
Or arrived with her.
No.
She didn't call anyone? Even locally?
No.
You didn't spend the whole night  with her did you?
No! Of all...
How do you know she didn't make a  call?

She was tired. She said she had a  long drive ahead of her, in the  morning... Yes, now I'm remembering  very clearly because I'm picturing.  When you make a picture of the moment  in your mind, you can remember every  detail. She was sitting back there,  no she was standing up, with some  sandwich still in her hand, and she  said she had to drive a long way.
Back where?
What do you mean?
You said she was sitting "back there,"  or standing rather...
Oh. My private parlor. She had an  awful hunger... so I made her some  supper. And then she went to bed and  left in the morning. I didn't even  see her leave.
How did she pay you?
What?
Cash or check? For the cabin...
Cash.
And when she left, she never came  back.
Why should she? I'm sorry, I have  work to do, Mr... if you don't mind...
I do mind. If it don't jell, it ain't  aspic! (smiles)
This ain't jelling.
I don't know what you expect me to  know about... people come and go...
She isn't still here, is she?
Not at all!
Suppose I wanted to search the cabins,  all twelve... would I need a warrant?
(as if pleasantly  exasperated)
Look, if you won't believe me, go  ahead. You can help me make beds if  you like. (laughs, shakes his  head)
Come on. He starts out. Arbogast pauses, momentarily confused by t young man's openness.

Norman walks down the porch, hesitates before Cabin One,  walks on a bit toward Cabin Two, stops, turns to see if  Arbogast is following. Arbogast has come out onto the por but is not following. He has walked to the opposite end o the porch and is standing at its edge, looking up at the house. The upstairs window is in darkness. The neon of th Vacancy and Motel signs splash strange light over the sce
Change your mind? Arbogast does not reply. Norman becomes apprehensive, sta to Arbogast, forcing himself to remain calm and cheerful.
I guess I've got one of those faces  you can't help believing.
(to Norman, but  continuing to stare  at the house)
Anyone at home?
I live there. Alone.
Someone is sitting in that window.
My mother. Arbogast turns, gazes seriously at him.
She's... ill. Confined to her room.  It's practically living alone.
(after a pause)
If this girl Mary Crane were here,  you'd have no reason to hide her  would you?
Of course not.
If she paid you well?
Now, look...!
Or if she had you say... gallantly  protecting her... you wouldn't be  fooled... you'd know she was just  using you. Wouldn't you?
I'm not a fool! And I'm not capable  of being fooled! Not even by women!
I didn't mean that as a slur on your  manhood. I'm sorry.
(disturbed now)
That's all right. maybe she could  have fooled me.  But... (a rueful smile)
She didn't fool my mother.
Your mother met her? (quickly)
Can I talk to your mother?
No. I told you, she's confined...
Just for a moment. She might have  picked up a hint you'd miss.
Sick old women are sharp. Come on, I  won't disturb...
No! Just no!  I have one of those  breaking points like any other man,  believe it or not, and I'm near it. There's just so much pushing I can  take and I think...
All right! (starts away, toward  his car, pauses)
Might save me a lot of leg-work if I  could just talk to your mother.  But  I'd need a warrant for that, won't

Norman does not respond. Arbogast gets in his car, starts the motor. Norman looks up, studies the man's face, his o face showing apprehension. Arbogast backs the car around  very slowly, his gaze divided between the old house and t lighted window of Cabin Two. As he turns the car out, his headlights light up the porch. Norman stands, watching him drive away.
The car pulls up and Arbogast gets out of car, leaving mo running. As he starts to walk across the highway, CAMERA  PULLS AWAY and we

Arbogast gets to the phone booth, enters. CAMERA STARTS  FORWARD, and we see Arbogast remove a small notebook from his pocket, check on a number, drop a dime in the slot an dial this number. As we reach phone booth,
(into phone)
Miss Crane, please. (listens)
She leave a number? (listens)
Thanks. (hangs up, dials again,  waits)
Lila there, Mr. Loomis? Arbogast. (waits)
Lila? Look, this isn't much, but it  might make you feel a little better.  Mary was up here. Spent last Saturday  night at Bates'  Motel, out here on  the old highway. (listens)
Young fellow runs it, said Mary spent  the night, left, period! (listens)
I did question him, believe me. I  think I got all there was to get.   Just have to try to pick up the scent  from here. (listens)

Well... maybe that's because I don't  feel entirely satisfied.  He's got a  sick old mother, confined type, and  I think she saw Mary and talked to  her. Shame, too... confined old women  love to talk to strangers. (listens)
I was, but I think I'll go back to  the motel, first. (listens)
No, you stay put, Lila. With Loomis.  I should be back in an hour. (listens)
All right. And Lila... You'll be  happy to know what I think. I think  our friend Sam Loomis didn't even  know Mary was here. (smiles)
See you in an hour. Or less. He hangs up, gets out of the phone booth.

A distant view of the House and Motel. There is a light o in the house. He goes over to the Motel offic

Arbogast looks around the empty office and calls.
Bates! He goes over to the door to the parlor and enters. He loo around the bird-ridden room. He stops short as he sees:

straightens up and goes out.

would go along but he stops with a new thought. He turns  around and looks off.
comes to a decision. He goes off.
dashes up the stone steps to the House.

CAMERA HOLDS as Arbogast goes up onto the porch. The hous is dark within except, as we can now see, for a faint spi of light in the foyer, light which comes from the upstair hall. Arbogast goes to the living room window, looks in,  sees only darkness. Then he goes to the door, listens for along moment, hears nothing. Very slowly, almost painfully, he turns the knob of the d and pushes gently with his arm and shoulder. The door beg to open. He allows it to open just enough for him to slip through and into the foyer.

Arbogast gradually eases the door closed, stands against waiting. He looks up in the direction of the light, sees one. The door at the head of the stairs is closed. Arboga listens, holds his breath, hears what could be human soun coming from upstairs but realizes these could also be the sounds of an old house after sunset. After a careful wait he crosses to the stairs, starts up, slowly, guardedly,  placing a foot squarely on each step to test it for squea or groans before placing his full weight on it. CAMERA  FOLLOWS, remaining on floor level but TRAVELLING ALONG th stairway as Arbogast makes his way up.

We see Arbogast coming up the stairs. And now we see, too the door of the mother's room, opening, carefully and slo As Arbogast reaches the landing, the door opens and the m steps out, her hand raises high, the blade of an enormous knife flashing.

The knife slashes across his cheek and neck. Blood spurts The sudden attack throws him off balance. He stumbles bac and staggers down the whole of the staircase. He frantica gropes for the balustrade as he goes backwards down the  stairs. The CAMERA FOLLOWS him all the way. A wicked knif keeps thrusting itself into the foreground. As he collaps at the bottom, the black head and shoulders of Mrs. Bates plunges into the foreground as the CAMERA MOVES IN to con the raising and descending murder weapon.

Lila is sitting close by the phone, and looks as if she h moved from it in the last hour. Sam is pacing, occasional stopping at the window, glancing out, pacing again. The a tray close to Lila is filled. There is a thick atmosphere of smoke, tension and wearine in the small, otherwise cozy room.
(at window, quietly)
Sometimes Saturday night has a lonely  sound. Ever notice, Lila?
(unable to keep up  small talk)
Sam. He said an hour. Or less.
It's been three.
Are we just going to go on sitting  here?
(suddenly cheerful)
He'll be back. Let's sit still and  hang on, okay?
You have an awfully nice habit, Sam.
Hundreds! Which one is your pet?
Whenever I start contemplating the  panic button, your back straightens up and your eyes get that God-looks- out-for-everybody look and... I feel  better.
I feel better when you feel better.
(a pause - then she  rises)
Where's the old highway?
You want to run out there, bust in  on Arbogast and the sick old lady,  shake her up and maybe spoil  everything Arbogast's been building  for the last three hours.
Yes.
That wouldn't be a wise thing to do.
Patience doesn't run in our family. Sam, I'm going out there!
Arbogast said...
An hour! Or less! Sam stares at her, frowns in concern over her very real  anxiety, goes to the phone, dials operator.
(into phone)
Got the number of the motel out on  the old highway? Bates, I think. (waits)
Sam! Why call when we can go?
And maybe pass Arbogast on the road? (into phone)
Thanks. He presses down the receiver, releases it, dials Bates' Motel. The faint other-end ringing tones can be heard,  repeatedly, annoyingly. He waits.
(to Lila)
Probably on his way back right now.
Sam, I'm going.
(hangs up and picks  up his jacket)
You'll never find it. He starts for the door. Lila follows after him into the s
He pauses halfway down, turns, puts his hands on her arms
Stay here.
Why can't I go out there with you?
(looks at her)
I don't know... (he collects himself)
One of us has to be here in case  Arbogast's on the way.
(nervously)
Just wait here?
(a warm smile)

Contemplate your... panic button. He hurries down to the street door and out. CAMERA HOLDS Lila as she stares after Sam. As she stands alone in the  darkened store, all the hardware seems to take on siniste shapes. C.U. Among some bathroom fittings a nozzle from a shower falls onto the floor.
Lila turns and picks if from the floor and puts it back i its place. She turns and again looks to the deserted stre with a touch of anxiety. She gives a slight unconscious  shiver.
Tall and lonely still against the moonlight, the figure o Norman, silhouetted. He doesn't move, merely stands there the edge of the swamp, staring down at the now calm and q face of it.

All light are out, except the light in Norman's mother's  room. And her figure can be seen sitting in the window,  relaxed in a high-back chair, her face turned into the ro After a second, we hear the SOUND OF A MOTOR, and then Sa small pick-up truck swings into the driveway. Sam stops the motor, automatically switches off headlight pauses as he observes the silence and darkness of the are Then he hops out of the cab, goes quickly to the office,  knocks on the door. As he waits for a response, he looks  down the long porch, studies the darkened cabins, knocks  again, louder, looks in the other direction and sees the  house and the figure at the one lit window. He stares a m then calls loudly:
Arbogast?

The silhouette of Norman. He is still. Over shot, very di comes the SOUND OF SAM'S VOICE, calling again for Arbogas Norman turns slowly until, in silhouette, we see his prof his chin lowered furtively as he looks over his shoulder the direction of the house. There is silence for a moment and then again the SOUND of Sam POUNDING at the door.

The store is in darkness, only the glow from the back roo spilling in. L.S. With CAMERA placed with its back to the street door, we c see the distant tiny figure of Lila seated and waiting in the back room beyond. There is a SOUND of a car pulling u The tiny figure jumps up and runs all the way from the ba room down the aisle of hardware and comes into a BIG HEAD We see Lila's desperate anxious look.
From her viewpoint we see Sam alighting from his truck an coming toward the door of the store. He enters. He and Li exchange quiet glances.
He didn't come back here?
(worriedly)
Sam.
No Arbogast. No Bates. And only the  old lady at home... (frowning)
A sick old lady unable to answer the  door... or unwilling.
Where could he have gone?
Maybe he got some definite lead. Maybe he went right on...
Without calling me?
In a hurry.
Sam, he called me when he had nothing  definite, nothing but a dissatisfied  feeling. Don't you think he'd have  called if he had anything...
(interrupting)

Yes. I think he would have. Lila goes quiet. Sam starts toward the back room, pauses the doorway, turns. Lila has remained by the door, lookin out at the street. She feels his pause, turns, and for a  moment they share at each other across the darkened room.
Let's go see Al Chambers.
Who's he?
He's the Deputy Sheriff around here. As he starts forward.

A dark, quiet, tree-ceilinged street, the small neat hous dim in the moonlight. Sam's pick-up truck comes down the  street, pulls up before the house of Sheriff Chambers. CA MOVES IN on Sam and Lila as they remain for a moment in t truck's cab, staring quietly at the sleeping house.
Our Deputy sleeps.
Well?
Nothing.  Just... all the lights  out... must be asleep.
(a small exasperation)
Does that mean we can't...
No. I'm just procrastinating.  People  hate when the doorbell rings in the  middle of the night. (gives up, starts out)

Come on. He gets out of cab, goes around to help Lila. She is alre out. CAMERA FOLLOWS them up the small path to the front d Sam presses the bell button. Both he and Lila are almost  knocked over by the shocking, clanging, ear-splitting BLA OF THE BELL within the house, a ring which sounds more li a fire alarm than a doorbell. He tries to smile, fails. Lila doesn't even try. The  downstairs hall light goes on and a moment later the door unhesitatingly opened by MRS. CHAMBERS, a small, lively s of a woman wrapped in a thick flannel robe and a corona o hospitality.
Oh?
Sorry, Mrs. Chambers. I hate bothering  you...
You didn't! (a cross look up at  the bell)
It's tinkerbell. (a quick smile at  Lila)
Al wants to be sure he'll hear it if  anyone rings it in the middle of the  night. (to Sam)
Well come on in, at least! As she opens the door wide,
Fat roses splatter the wallpaper. The stairs are carpeted The lighting is bright. There is a perfectly fitting wall phone by the parlor arc Mrs. Chambers goes to the stairway, yells up.
Albert! (a tiny wait, a smile  as Sam and Lila enter)

Al Chambers! Sam is about to close the door behind him. Mrs. Chambers  motions for him not to, scurries across the hall, leans  outside, presses the doorbell. The RING within the house even more shattering. She closes the door, starts to the  stairway, pauses as the SOUNDS of movement above COME OVE SHOT.

Customers! SHERIFF CHAMBERS comes down the stairs, in a bathrobe whi matches his wife's. He is a tall, narrow man with a face  originally destined for Mount Rushmore. He nods at Sam, l at him with wide-awake eyes and a no-nonsense concern.
We have a problem.
(to Lila)
Let's go out back and have some coca  while the men are talking.
No, thank you. It's my problem, too.
I don't know where to start... (a look at Lila)
Except at the beginning.
Yes.
(to Sheriff)

This is Lila Crane, from Phoenix. She's been here for a few days,  looking for her sister. There's a  private detective helping... and,  well, we got a call tonight, from  this detective, saying he'd traced  Mary...
Mary is Lila's sister?
Yes. He traced her to that motel,  out on the old highway...
(to the Sheriff)
Bates' Motel. (to Lila)
He has a mind like a mechanical brain  and the more information you feed  it... Go on, Sam.
He traced her there and called us to  say he was going to question Mrs.  Bates...
(a pleasant shock)
Norman took a wife?
No. An old woman, his mother. (to Sheriff, quickly)
That was early this evening. And we  haven't seen or heard from him since.   I went out to the motel, just got  back. No one was in the office, and...
(interrupting,  anxiously)
Will you help us? I think something's  wrong out there!
(after a considerate  pause)
Now. Your sister is missing how long?
She left Phoenix a week ago yesterday.  And no trace until...
How'd you and this detective come to  trace her to Fairvale?
They thought she'd be coming to me.
Left Phoenix under her own steam?
Yes.
(a pause)
She ain't missing so much as she's  run away.
Yes.
From what?
(a look at sam, then:)
She stole some money.
A lot?
Forty thousand dollars.
And the police haven't been able  to...
(interrupting)
Everyone concerned thought... if  they could get her to give back the  money... they could avoid involving  her with the police.
Explains the private detective. He  traced her to the Bates place.  What'd  he exactly say when he called you?
Mary had been there, one night, and  had left.
With the forty thousand dollars?
He didn't mention the money. (anxiously)
What he said on the phone isn't  important, is it?  He was supposed  to come back after he spoke to the  mother, and he didn't! That's what I  want you to do something about!
Like what?
Go out there! Find somebody, ask  some questions! (a pause)
I'm sorry if I seem over-anxious to  you. I keep thinking... something's  wrong. I have to know what!
I think something's wrong, too, Miss.  But not the same thing. I think your  private detective is what's wrong. (As Lila is about to  object)
I think he got himself a hot lead as  to where your sister was going...  probably from Norman Bates...  and  called you to keep you still while  he took off after her and the money.
He said he was dissatisfied... and  was going back.
(to Sheriff)
Why don't you call Norman and let  him say just what happened, if he  give the man a hot lead and he did  just scooted off... it'll make the  girl feel better, Albert.
At this hour?
He was out when I was there. If he's  back he probably isn't even in bed  yet.
He wasn't out when you were there.   He just wasn't answering the door in  the dead of night... like some people  do. This fellow lives like a hermit...
Recluse. Kinder word.
(to Sam)
You must remember that bad business  out there. About ten years ago...
I've only been here five. Right now  it feels like ten, but...
All right! Then call! At least, call! Mrs. Chambers goes to phone, dials operator.
(into phone)

Florrie, the Sheriff wants you to  connect him with the Bates Motel. She hands the receiver to the Sheriff. He takes it,  reluctantly, listens to the dim sound of RINGING on the o end. After a moment:
(into phone)
Norman? Sheriff Chambers. (listens)
Been just fine, thanks. Listen, we  got some worries here. Did you have  a man stop out there tonight... (listens)
Well, this one wouldn't be a customer,  anyway. A private detective, name  of...
Arbogast.
(into phone)
Arbogast. (listens)
And after he left? (listens)
No, it's okay, Norman. How's it been  going out there? (listens)
Well, I think you oughta unload that  place and open up closer in to the  action, a smaller place, you know...  but...
Please!
(into phone)
Sorry I got you up, boy. Go back to  sleep. Yeah, be glad to. (hangs up, turns to  Mrs. Chambers)
Said to give you his regards.
(faint irony)
Was that all?
This detective was out there and  Norman told him about the girl and  the detective thanked him and went  away.
And he didn't go back? Didn't see  the mother? The Sheriff looks long at Lila, shakes his head  sympathetically.
You should've called in the police  the second you found your sister has  skipped. You go starting private  investigations, using people you  don't even know...
What difference does that...
Your Detective told you a nakedfaced  lie.
Barefaced.
He told you he wasn't coming right  back cause he wanted to question  Norman Bates' mother, right?
Yes.
(a pause, then calmly)
Norman Bates' mother has been dead  and buried in Greenlawn Cemetery for  the last ten years! There is a long silence. Sam and Lila stare at the Sherif
I helped Norman pick out the dress  she was buried in. Periwinkle blue.

It ain't only local history, Sam,  it's the only murder-and-suicide  case in Fairvale ledgers! Mrs. Bates poisoned this guy she was...  involved with, when she found out he  was married, then took a helping of  the same stuff herself.  Strychnine.  Ugly way to die.
Norman found them dead together.  In  bed.
You mean that old woman I saw sittin'  in the window wasn't Norman Bates'  mother?
(hopefully, happily)
Maybe you saw Mary!
I'd know the difference between Mary  and an old woman.
Now wait a minute, Sam. You sure you  saw an old woman?
Yes! In the house behind the motel.  I pounded and called but she... just  ignored me.
And you want to tell me you saw Norman  Bates' mother.

It must've been. Arbogast said so,  too... and he said the young man  wouldn't let him see her because she  was ill! The Sheriff stares at both of them, and when he finally s there is an almost inaudible tone or irony in his voice.
Well, if the woman up there is Mrs. Bates... who's that woman buried out  at Greenlawn Cemetery?

Norman sits in the dim, one-lamp light, the phone next to him, his hand still near it as if he had not been able to move his hand after hanging up. He is staring at the shri like bird which is perched on the lamp shade. Decision an resolution are beginning to show in his face. Suddenly he rises, starts quickly out of the room, tries to switch of the lamp as he goes and in so doing succeeds only in knoc the bird off the shade. He watches it fall, does not try to catch it. It hits the floor with a thud and sawdust spills out. He stares sadly it, for a moment, then tends down, scoops up the sawdust, tries to press it into the split seam, picks up the bird, puts it in a drawer. Then he puts out the lamp, goes out, crosses the darkened office and goes outside.
Norman comes off the porch, walks to the path and directl up to the house, opens the door and goes in.

Norman goes up, pauses one moment outside his mother's do then opens it and goes in, leaving the door open. For a moment we hear only Norman's low, quiet voice, his  words indistinguishable. Then we hear the cold shot of hi mother's derisive laughter.
I am sorry, boy, but you do manage  to look ludicrous when you give me  orders!
Please, mother...
(Sharp, laughter all  gone)
No! I will not hide in the fruit  cellar! (A shrill laugh)
Think I'm fruity, huh? (Hard, cold again)
I'm staying right here!  This is my  room and no one will drag me out of  it... least of all my big bold son!
(Rising now, anxiously)
They'll come now, Mother. He came  after the girl and now someone will  come after him! How long do you think  you can go on... Mother, please,  just for a few days, just so they  won't find you!
(Mimicking)
Just for a few days... (Furious)
In that dank fruit cellar? No!  You  hid me there once, boy, and you won't  do it again! Not ever again!  Now  get out! (A pause, quiet)
I told you to get out, boy! (A longer pause)
Norman! What do you think you're  going to do? Don't you touch me! Don't! Norman! (A pause, then  cajolingly)

All right, son, put me down and I'll  go. I'll go on my own two feet. I  can go on my own two feet, can't I? During all this the CAMERA has been slowly creeping up th stairs. It does not stop at the top however, but continue on the same high angle that we had in Scene 57. She starts to laugh, a terrible sound like an obscene mel

I'll carry you, mother. Norman comes out of the room, his mother held in his arms her head leaning against his shoulder. He carries her dow the stairs, along the lower landing to the cellar stairs, and then down those stairs to the basement.

An overcast morning, but a sunny-faced crowd. The service just over, there is contentment, and peace, and just a li I-went-to-church-smugness in the faces of the churchgoers they come out of the chapel, and spread their separate wa away. Amongst the crowd, waiting and searching the faces, are S and Lila. In their expressions there is no peace, no  contentment. CAMERA MOVES IN CLOSE. They are not speaking Lila looks as if she has had no sleep. Suddenly, Sam becomes alert, takes Lila's arm, starts tow the church. CAMERA MOVES WITH THEM, stops as they approach Sheriff an Mrs. Chambers. The Sheriff stares rather sympathetically Lila. Mrs. Chambers smiles nicely.
We thought, if you didn't mind, we'd  go out to the motel with you.
He's already been.
Went out before service.
Have you two had breakfast?
(To Sheriff, not a  question)
You didn't find anything.
Nothing. Here, let's clear the path. He moves away and the others follow. CAMERA PANS them to curb.
(Interrupting)
Did he say anything about my sister?
Just what he told your detective. She used a fake name, saw the register myself. Saw the wh place, as a matter of fact. That boy is alone there.
No mother.
You must've seen an illusion, Sam. Now, I know you're not the seeing- illusion type... But no woman was  illusion there and I don't believe  in ghosts, so there it is!
I still feel...

Can see you do. Sorry I couldn't  make you feel better. You want to  come to my office this afternoon and  report a missing person... And the  theft, is what you want to do!  Sooner  you drop this thing in the lap of  the law, that's the sooner you'll  stand a chance of your sister bein'  picked up. How about that?
I don't know.

It's Sunday. Come over and do the  reporting at the house, 'round dinner  time. Make it nicer. You too, Sam. She smiles brightly, as if having invited them over to di this year's charity fandango, takes the Sheriff's arm, starts away. The Sheriff nods as he goes. Sam and Lila are alone now, at the curb, before the deser chapel. For a long moment they just stand there, their fa as gray and overcast as the sky.
Maybe I am the seeing-illusions type.
You're not. Sam takes her arm, starts walking her up the street towar the spot where his pick-up truck is parked. CAMERA FOLLOWS them.
Want me to drop you at the hotel?   Or you want to come over to the store? Lila does not answer. They reach the truck. Lila looks  directly at Sam as he helps her into the cab.
I won't feel satisfied unless I got  out there, Sam.
Neither will I. He slams the door, hurries around truck, gets into driver seat, starts motor. As the truck drives off,
For a moment, both are silent; Sam watching the road as i there were other cars on it, Lila staring at nothing in  particular, except perhaps her own inner fear.
I wonder if we'll ever see Mary again.
Of course we will.
Alive. Sam looks as if he'd like to say something humorous, some to cheer her. He cannot. He remains silent.
We lived together all our lives. When we woke up one morning and found ourselves orphans,  Mary quit college and got a job, so I could go to college
Where'd you go to college?
I didn't. I got a job, too. (A pause)
I wonder if that hurt her, my not  letting her sacrifice for me?  Some  people are so willing to suffer for  you that they suffer more if you  don't let them.
(Almost to himself)
She was willing to lick the stamps. Lila looks quizzically at him, is too concerned to pursue it.
I wonder so many things about her  now.  Why she never told me about  you...  Funny, when you think there's  an answer to everything, you think  you know all the answers.
We were going to get married. Are  going to get married!
Do you know how I found out about  you? I found one of your letters...  it was a nice letter, Sam.
This is the old highway.
I suppose... when you were able to  marry her she'd have presented you,  all shiny and proper... she always  tried to be proper.
Watch your tenses.
Huh?
She always tries to be proper. Sam slows the truck to a stop, sighs, starts to light up cigarette. Lila looks questioningly and impatiently at hi
You going to wait here for me?
I'm going with you. But we'd better  decide what we're going to say and  do when we walk in...
We're going to register. As man and  wife. And get shown to a cabin...  and then search every inch of that  place, inside and... outside.
You won't believe it... (Starts motor)
But this will be the first time I've ever pulled one of those man- and-wife-renting-cabin capers!
(A tiny smile, first  in hours)
I believe it. As truck starts to drive on,
The place is empty and silent and washed dirty by the dee gray of the cloudy sky. We see Sam's truck turning into t driveway and pulling to a stop. After a moment, Sam and L get out of the truck.

Close on Sam and Lila as they meet on the porch side of t truck. The motel office and the house beyond can be seen b.g. of shot. Sam and Lila merely stare for a moment, the turn and gaze up at the house. There is no figure in the  window and the shade is drawn. Same goes to the office do peers in, knocks, opens door, enters. Lila remains on the driveway, beside the truck.

CLOSE ANGLE on Norman standing by the window. He has pull the curtains very slightly apart, is staring out and down the motel, his eyes studying the lone figure of Lila, who standing by the truck and looking up at the house.  Norma studies her, and as her eyes look up at this very window closes the curtains, turns away. We see the suspicion and fear in his face, the surge of p and his struggle to contain it. Then he goes away. CAMERA remains on window, shooting out and down, and through the frail curtains we can see Sam as he comes out of the mote office and joins Lila.
(Unconsciously  whispering)
I wonder where Norman Bates does his  hermiting?
Someone was at that window. I saw  the curtain move. Sam takes Lila's arm.

Come on. He starts with her toward the path which leads to the old house. CAMERA PANS with them, and as they turn around the office corner, they see Norman coming down the path towar them. They pause and Norman pauses. He does not smile, no speak. His usual grin and soft friendliness are gone;  containment and impassivity lie in their place.
(Cheerfully)
Just coming up to ring for you.
(Coming forward)
I suppose you want a cabin.

We'd hoped to make it straight to  San Francisco, but we don't like the  look of that sky. Looks like a bad  day coming... doesn't it. Norman walks past Sam, giving him the sort of quick,  disapproving glance one gives a man who is obviously lyin goes onto the porch and into the office. Sam and Lila fol Norman.
Norman crosses to the desk, goes behind it, takes the key cabin number twelve off the keyboard. Sam and Lila have  entered and are almost to the desk-counter by this time.
I'll take you to...
Better sign in first, hasn't we? Sam eyes scan the counter, looking for a registration boo
It isn't necessary.
(Interrupting with a  friendly cheerfulness)

Uh, uh! My boss is paying for this  trip... ninety percent business...  and he wants practically notarized  receipts. I better sign in and get a  receipt. Norman stares at Sam, as if he'd like to yell at him, cal him "liar." Instead he reaches under the desk counter, br out the registration book. Lila moves closer, studies the book as Sam signs in. Sam signs "Joe and Mrs. Johnson." signature and city of "Marie Samuels" and after it, the  notation "Cabin One," can be clearly seen three registrat above Sam's. When Sam has finished he closes book, hands it back to No Norman does not take it, starts out from behind counter.
I'll get your bags.
Haven't any.
(after a stare)
I'll show you the cabin. As he starts for the door, Sam laughs. Norman stops, turn looks at him.
First time I've seen it happen. (to Lila)
Check in any place in this country  without bags, and you have to pay in  advance. Sam smiles as if at a funny remark, takes a bill out of h pocket.
Ten dollars... Norman returns to Sam, takes the extended bill, is about start out again.

That receipt...? Norman goes reluctantly behind counter, lays down the key cabin twelve, takes a receipt book out of the drawer unde counter, starts to write. Lila steps up to the desk, pick up the key, quickly, starts out.
I'll start ahead. Norman looks up, gazes her as she goes out door.
Lila comes along the porch, pauses before cabin one, trie the door. It opens. She closes it quickly as she hears Sa and Norman coming out of the motel office, continues on d the porch.
(To Norman, who is  following)

Don't bother yourself... we'll find  it. He goes on down the porch, doesn't even glance at cabin o walks quickly and catches up to Lila just as she reaches  cabin twelve. CAMERA REMAINS with Norman, who is standing the office door, looking after Sam and Lila, his face ale and no longer impassive. He waits a moment, after they ha closed their cabin door, then crosses to the pickup truck CAMERA MOVES with him. He studies the truck, then leans i through the driver's window, twists the registration card around, reads it. It gives the correct name and address of Sam Loomis. Norman comes back out of the window, glances once more to cabin twelve, then at the old house. His suspicions are  confirmed, and now there is the relaxation of relief in h face. He takes on a purposeful air, turns, strides up the path, up onto the porch of the house, opens the door, goe in.

Lila is at the cabin's rear window, looking out, strainin for a glimpse of the old house, which cannot be seen from the window of this cabin. She turns, frustrated, anxious. Sam is standing at the fo of the bed, staring at the smooth coverlet, his brow crea in a sadness.
We should have asked for Cabin One...  The one Mary was in.

I'm glad we didn't. He pulls his eyes from the bed, crosses to the desk, sits wearily, lights a cigarette. Lila watches him for a momen feels a real compassion, goes to the bed, sits on its edg turns again and looks at Sam's back.
We have to go into that cabin and  search it, Sam... no matter what  we're afraid of finding and no matter  how much it may hurt.
I know. (A pause)
Do you think if something happened,  it happened there?
(A pause, then:)
Sam, if you owned a useless business  like this motel... one you probably  couldn't even sell...  what would  you need to get away, to start a new  business, somewhere else? (As Sam studies her)
Forty thousand dollars?
How could we prove... (An almost hopeless  laugh)
Well, if he opens a new motel on the  new highway... say, a year from now...
There must be some proof that exists  right now! Something that proves he  got that money away from Mary...  Some way!
What makes you sound so certain?

Arbogast! Sam, he liked me... or  felt sorry for me... and he was  starting to feel the same about you.  I heard it when he called... in his  voice, a caring. He wouldn't have  gone anywhere or done anything without  telling us.  Unless he was stopped.  And he was stopped, so he must have  found out something! Sam considers a moment, nods agreement, rises.
We'll start with Cabin One. He goes to the door, opens it slightly, looks out, then,  back to Lila:
If he sees us... we're just taking  the air. Lila goes to the door. He holds it open and she goes out.

Sam closes the door, joins Lila, takes her hand. Together they walk along the porch in the direction of Ca One. CAMERA FOLLOWS. They pause before the door of Cabin  One. Sam motions Lila to wait, to hold still, then goes o to the office, opens the door, calls in:
Bates? He waits, there is no response. He goes in and in a momen comes back out, closes the door, goes to Lila. She has already opened the door of Cabin One and has star to enter.

The blinds are closed and the room is almost night-dark. Sam comes in after Lila, closes the door behind him. For a moment they just gaze at the room, as if willing it tell them some satisfactory story. Neither speaks. Then, in dark silence, they begin to sear going methodically and thoroughly through all drawers, th closet, the desk, searching under the bed and in dark cor not knowing what they expect to find and yet expecting to find some thing. Lila opens the bathroom door, looks in. windowless room is very dark. She switches on the light,  goes in. Sam moves toward the bathroom, is about to follo her in when he notices which room it is and automatically catches himself up, backs out.
Sorry.
Hospital clean.
What?

The bathroom. Look at how clean it  is. The one in our cabin is clean...  but this is clean! Sam goes in, glances around, nods. Lila goes through the  medicine cabinet, finds nothing but a glass and two tiny  tabs of soap. Sam leans against the door-jamb, looks at t tub, the shower pipe above it. He continues to stare, mor interested suddenly, as if bothered by some off-key evide he can't put his finger on. Then he looks at the shower  curtain rod. And realizes there is no shower curtain. He frowns, is ab to say something when Lila, who has been momentarily out shot, interrupts. Sam turns, CAMERA TURNS, and we see Lila is standing abov the toilet bowl, a tiny piece of wet paper stuck to the t of her right index finger.
What is it?
It didn't get washed down. It's  figuring... the kind you tear up and  get rid of. (Extending her finger  toward Sam)

Some figure has been added to or  subtracted from... forty thousand. Sam lifts the piece of paper off her finger, studies it,  takes out his wallet, presses the wet scrap to his driver license shield, puts it back in the wallet and puts the w away.
That's proof Mary was here!  It would  be too wild a coincidence for somebody  else to...
(Reminding)
Bates never denied Mary was here.
(Reminded)
Yes. (A thought)
But maybe this proves that Bates  found out about the money.
Do we simply ask him where he's hidden  it?
Sam, that old woman, whoever she is.  I think she told Arbogast something!  And I want her to tell us the same  thing! She starts out of the bathroom. Sam takes hold of her arm stops her.
You can't go up there.
Why not?
Bates. CAMERA STARTS TO PAN AWAY from them, moves slowly over th room, very slowly.
Let's find him. One of us can keep  him occupied while the other gets to  the woman.

You won't be able to hold him still  if he doesn't want to be held. And I  don't like you going into that house  alone, Lila. CAMERA HAS PANNED clear across to the opposite wall now, is moving up closer and closer to the tiny-flowered wall  paper, finally closing in on one small rosebud.
I can handle a sick old woman. Now we see that the rosebud has been cut out, that this i the reverse side of the hole Norman peeped through to wat Mary. And we see the pupil of Norman's eye now.
All right. I'll find Bates and keep  him occupied. The eye moves away and there is a brief flash of light be the hole is covered, on the other side, by the wall-hung  painting.
They are about to start out. Sam stops her again.
Wait a minute. If you get anything  out of the mother... (A thought)
Can you find your way back to town? (As Lila nods yes)

If you do get anything, don't stop  to tell me. Lila nods quickly, hurries to the door. Sam gets to it fi opens it a slight crack, looks out, then opens it wide en for Lila and Himself to pass through.

ANGLE CLOSE on cabin one as Lila comes out, turns to her  left, goes along porch toward cabin twelve. Sam remains a the door, then turns right, heading for the path. As he p the office, he is shocked to see Norman standing just ins the open door.
Looking for me?
(Recovering)
Yes, matter of fact. (The friendly grin)
The wife's taking a nap and... I can  never keep quiet enough for her...  so I thought I'd look you up and...  talk.
Satisfied with your cabin?
Fine. Sam starts into the office. Just before going in, he glan down the long porch, sees Lila standing outside the door cabin twelve, waves her a tiny "all clear" signal.

CAMERA ANGLES to include Lila and her point of view. She watches Sam disappear into the office, waits until sh hears the door close, then looks about for another way to reach the house. She sees the small alley at the end of t L of cabins, starts toward it.
Behind the motel Lila hesitates. She looks ahead.
The old house standing against the sky.
Lila moves forward.
The CAMERA approaching the house.
Lila glances toward the back of Norman's parlor. She move on.
The house coming nearer.
Lila looks up at the house. She moves forward purposefull
The house and the porch.
Lila stops at the house and looks up. She glances back. She turns to the house again.
The CAMERA MOUNTS the steps to the porch.
Lila puts out her hand.
Lila's hand pushes the door open. We see the hallway. Lila ENTERS PAST CAMERA.

Lila closes the door, remains by it for a moment, quiet,  listening. Her eyes scan the layout, the closed door whic leads off the hallway, to the dining room on the right an the parlor on the left. Down at the end of the hall is th kitchen, the door wide open, the room beyond dim and sile She notices the stairs leading down to the basement, star at them, then back to the stairs leading to the second fl She starts forward, and seems about to investigate the pa and dining room.

Norman is behind the counter, standing, staring at Sam wh is sitting relaxedly on a small sofa. Norman has the look one who is protecting himself, as if the counter were a  protective wall against the threatening world across it.
(Cheerfully, as if  after a self-conscious  pause)
I've been doing all the talking so  far, haven't I?
Yes.
I always thought it was the people  who are alone so much who do all the  talking when they get the chance.  Yet there you are, doing all the  listening! (A pause)
You are alone here, aren't you? (As Norman does not  reply)
It would drive me crazy.
That would be a rather extreme  reaction, wouldn't it?
(Lightly)
Just an expression... (More seriously)
What I meant was... I'd do just about  anything... to get away.  Wouldn't  you?

location: DOWNSTAIRS HALLWAY AND STAIRS OF OLD HOUSE

text: Lila is halfway up the stairs. As she climbs she is start by the creaks and groans of the old wood of the steps. Sh steps more carefully. CAMERA remains at foot of stair, TI UP as Lila climbs. She pauses at the head of the stair. T door on her right, which opens into the mother's room, is closed. To her left is another door, half-open. Directly  before her is a third door, closed. She holds a long mome trying to picture in her mind which room would look out o the front of the house, decides, chooses the correct door the one on her right. She goes to it, knocks lightly.
We hear Lila's second knock, then, faintly, her soft call

Mrs. Bates? There is quiet for a moment, then the door begins to open and we see Lila. She stands on the threshold, looking in the room, instantly disturbed by it, almost chilled, her  expression indicating an impulse to close the door and go away from this room forever. After a moment, she enters, leaving the door open behind  her. CAMERA PULLS BACK AND AWAY and we now see the room a Lila sees it. It is ornate, damask-and-mahogany, thick and warm and rip an olla podrida of mismated furnishings and bric-a-brac o the last century. The bed is four poster, but uncanoped; dressing table is fancy and flounced with satin; there is great chiffonier, a big-doored wardrobe, a large, oval, f length pier-glass (this against the wall directly opposit the door), a satin recamier, an upholstered armchair by t window, a white marble fireplace, its grate cold but pile with ashes. And there is in the room an unmistakably live quality, as even though it is presently unoccupied, it has not been l vacated by some musty presence. Lila glances at the bed. The damask coverlet is thrown ov it, but it is not neat, there is the imprint of a body on it, a body which obviously has slept in a curled-up, womb like position. Lila stares at it for a moment, up, then g to the dressing table. Its top is scattered with boxes an jars of cosmetics and creams, traces of fresh powder, an  opened bottle or perfume, a comb, and a brush with traces hair in its bristles. Lila moves on, catches a glimpse of herself in the pier-glass, is startled, turns away, goes the chiffonier, is about to open a drawer, sees the high  wardrobe out of the corner of her eyes, goes to it,  hesitantly. She opens one door. Fresh, clean, well presse dresses hang neatly. Lila opens the other door. The sweat and dresses and robes hang freely, none in moth-proof, st type bags. There is even a well-brushed collar of foxes. Along the floor of the wardrobe is a line of clean, polis shoes. Lila stares, then closes the door, turns, looks on again over the whole room, starts out,

location: THE UPSTAIRS HALLWAY OF THE OLD HOUSE

text: Lila comes out of the mother's room, closes the door behi her, looks down the stairs, then starts across the hall t the room whose door is half-open. The room within is dark the shades drawn full. Lila pauses on the threshold, reaches in, feels the wall, throws on a switch.
Sam has risen, is standing by the counter now.
I'm not saying you shouldn't be  contented here, I'm just doubting  that you are. I think if you saw a  chance to get out from under...   you'd unload this place...
(Angrily)
This place! This isn't 'a place.'   It's my only world. I grew up in  that house back there. I was a happy  child. My mother and I... we were  more than happy.
And now that your mother's dead? Norman snaps a sharp, fast, ugly look at him.
My mother is not dead!
(Softly)
I didn't think so.

location: NORMAN'S ROOM IN THE OLD HOUSE

text: Lila is standing in the doorway, staring at the room in s dismay. The room is grotesque, a horrible, ludicrous fant of childhood held beyond the point of decency. It is a small room. The walls are fancied with romping  silhouettes of teddy-bears and sailboats and carousels an fat cows jumping over aghast moons. The bed is small, far too short for a man of Norman's height. And yet the rumpl covers indicate that it is in this bed that Norman sleeps Next to the bed is an old-fashioned toy chest. On its top there are a bird-in-a-cage lamp, a plain-bound book, and ash tray filled with ashes and cigarette stubs. A grown m shirt hangs on a child's clothes tree. Against one wall there is a narrow, high bookcase filled  with thick, unchildish-looking books. On the small, white chest of drawers there is an old, child's victrola. The r on the turntable is discovered, on close inspection, to b Beethoven's Eroica Symphony. Lila studies the room, fascinated and repelled. She glanc at the bookcase, comes into the room, goes to the bookcas and pulls out a thick, large, plain-bound book. She opens it. Her eyes go wide in shock. And then there is disgust. She slams the book closed, drops it.

Norman, behind the counter, has moved back against the wa Sam is still on the other side of the counter, but is lea forward, his eyes hard on Norman's face. Norman's face is no longer expressionless. It has the sta high sheen of a cornered animal.
(Pressing)
You look frightened. Have I been  saying something frightening?
I don't know what you've been saying.
I've been talking about your mother...  about your motel. How are you going  to do it?
Do what?
Buy a new one! In a new town! Where you won't have to hide your  mother!
Shut up!
Where will you get the money to do  that, Bates... or do you already  have it... socked away... a lot of  it...
Leave me alone!
...Forty thousand dollars!
Leave me alone! He is close to panic now. He turns, swiftly, dashes back  into his private parlor. Sam goes quickly around the coun follows.

Norman hears Sam following, wants to run, to never be rea by this man. He crosses the small room, drawn to the rear window, as if he might fly through it. Sam enters, pauses Norman turns, back against the window, as unable to fly a as are the many still, stuffed birds. Sam registers a bri flicker of reaction when he sees the birds, but continues gaze at Norman, hard.

I bet your mother knows where the  money is. And what you did to get  it. And I think she'll tell us. Something self-assured and confident in Sam's tone gives  Norman a new, more terrified alarm. He turns his head, gl out the window at the old house. He looks back at Sam and there is terror in his voice.
Where's that girl? The girl you came  with! Where is she? Sam does not respond, smiles a half-smile, turns to exami a stuffed owl. Norman looks back at the house.
(A horrible groan)
Oh, God!

location: UPSTAIRS HALL OF THE OLD HOUSE

text: Lila, shaken and disturbed, almost sickened, is coming ou of Norman's room. She has left the light on. She pauses i the middle of the landing, looks at the closed door oppos the stairs, goes to it, opens it, sees that it is the  bathroom, pulls the door to, turns, starts toward the sta

Sam is lying on the floor, face downward, unmoving. A  candlestick is on the floor, close by his head, still roc as if just dropped. OVER SHOT comes the SOUND of Norman's footsteps and CAMERA TURNS in time to catch a brief glimp of him going out into the office, almost at a run.

Lila is on the top step, looking down toward CAMERA. She is listening, hoping to hear some human sound, some s she might follow, pursue. She hears nothing. She starts d the stairs. Just below the halfway step, she looks at the front door, sees out through the door window:
Norman coming.

For a moment Lila panics, then she hurries down the steps cannot go in the direction of the front door, remembers t stairway behind her, turns and runs in that direction. Th SOUND of Norman bounding up the porch steps can be heard. Lila turns and dashes down the stairs which lead to the  basement, going down far enough to conceal herself, crouc there. Norman enters the hallway, closes the door softly, listen He glances once in the direction of the basement stairs. seems about to smile, when suddenly all expression vanish from his face, and he appears to enter a no-place, no-tim state. He crosses to the stairway, goes up. Lila remains crouched on the basement stairs, listening t the SOUNDS of Norman. His footsteps on the stairs followe by the fast noises of doors opening, of fast moving about upstairs room. Convinced that he is searching the upstair for her, she decides to chance an escape. She starts up t steps, is about to turn into the hallway when her eye is  caught by a glimmer of light down in the basement. She pa looks down, sees the crack of light coming from behind th not entirely closed door to the fruit cellar. The swift m SOUNDS of Norman continue to come from upstairs. Lila is torn, knows she should get out of the house while she has the chance, is unable to resist the impulse to ch that hidden-looking room down below, a room in which, she desperately believes, there must lie some answer to what  happened to Mary. She turns and goes softly and quickly d the stairs.

location: THE BASEMENT OF THE OLD HOUSE

text: Lila reaches the bottom, stops, listens, hears the stairb creaking as footsteps fall hard and measured upon them. S turns, pulls open the fruit cellar door, looks in. The wo is sitting in a comfortable chair, the back of the chair, and the woman, turned to the door. Lila calls a harsh,  frightened whisper.
Mrs. Bates...? Lila goes into the room.

Lila goes to the chair, touches it. The touch disturbs th figure. It starts to turn, slowly, stiffly, a clock-wise  movement. Lila looks at it in horror. It is the body of a woman long dead. The skin is dry and pulled away from the mouth and the teeth are revealed as in the skeleton's smi The eyes are gone from their sockets, the bridge of the n has collapsed, the hair is dry and wild, the cheeks are  sunken, the leathery-brown skin is powdered and rouged an flaky. The body is dressed in a high-neck, clean, well-pr dress, obviously recently laundered and hand-ironed. The movement of this stuffed, ill-preserved cadaver, turn as if in response to Lila's call and touch, is actually  graceful, ballet-like, and the effect is terrible and obs Lila gazes for one flicker of a deathly moment, then begi to scream, a high, piercing, dreadful scream. And Lila's scream is joined by another scream, a more  dreadful, horrifying scream which comes from the door beh her.
(screaming)
Ayeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeee Am Norma  Bates! Lila turns.

His face is contorted. He wears a wild wig, a mockery of woman's hair. He is dressed in a high-neck dress which is similar to that worn by the corpse of his mother. His han is raised high, poised to strike at Lila. There is a long breadknife in it.
Close on her face. She is dumb-struck. Her eyes are screa

As he is about to start forward, a man's hand reaches in  from the doorway behind, grabs Norman's wrist. Sam comes  through the door, still holding tight to the wrist, pulli back the arm and at the same time throwing himself at Nor football tackle style.
Norman and Sam, struggling. The wild fury in Norman's fac the mad noise of his screams and vile curses. The terrifi fight-to-the-death look of Sam. The still, staring Lila.
A close of her face, She appears to be watching and enjoy the fight. Over the shot, the SOUNDS of the struggle, the screams of Norman.

There are many people gathered about the steps, the curio and the concerned and the morbid. At the curb, a couple o newspaper cars, two or three police cars, and a mobile un truck from the local television outlet. There is noise, a chattering as questions are asked and answers given, and sounds of traffic, and of the television equipment being  moved into the courthouse, for on-the-scene reporting, an the stern voices of policemen trying to keep people back. The scene has a bright glare about it, that quality of su light thrown on a fearful darkness.

A POLICEMAN trying to make way for the television men,  muttering "keep back," etc., to the spectators. A TELEVIS MAN, carrying a piece of equipment goes through door, and CAMERA FOLLOWS him into the courthouse vestibule. Here, too, there is a crowd, composed of Policemen, Repor Television Men. The Television Men we have been following stops beside a Policeman.
(Indicating the front  door he has just  come in through)
You think they'll take him out that  way?
(Looking at waiting  crowd, shrugging)
Probably have to. (A rueful smile)

Besides, the taxpayers hate it when  something gets slipped out the back  door on them! Over this exchange, the buzz of other voices, the movemen of men. CAMERA MOVES ON, down the corridor, gets to the d of the office of the Chief of Police just as a young fell with a carton box filled with paper containers of sent-ou for coffee reaches this door. CAMERA HOLDS as the COFFEE pauses a moment, then goes into the room.

location: OFFICE OF THE CHIEF OF POLICE

text: Lila is seated in a chair, Sam standing close by. A bit a from them, we see Sheriff Chambers, in quiet conference w the CHIEF OF POLICE, the COUNTY SHERIFF, the DISTRICT  ATTORNEY. The Coffee Boy stands in the doorway. Sam goes to him, ta a container of coffee from the box, carries it to Lila,  checking the notation on the lid as he goes.
(quietly)
It's regular. Okay?
(ruefully)

I could stand something regular. Sam smiles encouragingly, hands her the coffee. Sheriff  Chambers ENTERS SHOT, gives Sam a container of coffee he brought for him. Sam takes it, nods a thank you. For a moment no one speaks. Lila looks badly shaken, Sam  disheveled, but contained.
You two can go on home if you like. (a sympathetic look  at Lila)
Making that statement was enough for  one night.
(to Lila)
Want to?
No. I'm all right. I'll feel better  when all this is explained... if it  can be. Sam looks a question at Sheriff Chambers. Chambers shrugs doubtfully.
If anybody gets any answers, it'll  be the fellow talking to him now...  the Psychiatrist. Even I couldn't  reach Norman... and he knows me. (to Lila)
You warm enough, Miss? Lila is about to answer, when she sees someone come into room and rises anxiously. Sam and Sheriff Chambers turn,  follow her gaze.
A young man with a serious, frowning face has just come i the room. He is DR. SIMON, the Psychiatrist. He goes to the desk where the box of coffee containers ha been placed, takes up a container.
Did he talk to you?
No. I got the whole story... but not  from Norman. I got it from... his  mother. Everyone gazes at him, mystified. He speaks as he removes lid from coffee container.
Norman Bates no longer exists. He  only half-existed to begin with...   now, the other half has taken over.   Probably for all time.
(With difficulty)
Did he kill my sister?
Yes... and no.
Look, if you're trying to lay a lot  of psychiatric groundwork for some  sort of plea this fellow would like  to cop...
A psychiatrist doesn't lay the  groundwork .. he merely tries to  explain it.
But my sister is...
Yes. I'm sorry. (to Chambers)
The Private Investigator, too. If  you drag that swamp somewhere in the  vicinity of the motel... (To the Chief of Police)
Have you any unsolved missing persons  cases on your books?
Yes. Two.
Young girls?
(nods, astounded,  then:)
Did he confess to...
(interrupting)
As I said, the mother... (Pauses, goes on afresh)

To understand it, as I understood it  hearing it from the mother...  That  is, from the mother-half of Norman's  mind, you have to go back ten years...  to the time when Norman murdered his  mother and her lover. (A pause, then as no  one interrupts)

He was already dangerously disturbed,  had been ever since his father died.  His mother was a clinging, demanding  woman... and for years the two of  them lived as if there was no one  else in the world. Then she met a  man and it seemed to Norman she "threw  him over" for this man. That pushed  him over the thin line... and he  killed them both. Matricide is  probably the most unbearable crime  of all... and most unbearable to the  son who commit it. So he had to erase  the crime, at least in his own mind. (A pause)

He stole her corpse... and a weighted  coffin was buried. He hid the body  in the fruit cellar, even "treated"  it to keep it as well as it would  keep. And that still wasn't enough.  She was there, but she was a corpse.   So he began to think and speak for  her, gave her half his life, so to  speak. At times he could be both  personalities, carry on  conversations... at other times, the  mother-half took over completely. He  was never all Norman, but he was  often only mother. And because he  was so pathologically jealous of  her, he assumed she was as jealous  of him. Therefore, if he felt a strong  attraction to any other woman, the  mother side of him would go wild. (To Lila)

When Norman met your sister, he was  touched by her... and aroused by  her. He wanted her. And this set off  his "jealous mother" and...  "mother  killed the girl." After the murder,  Norman returned as if from a deep  sleep... and like a dutiful son,  covered up all traces of the crime  he was convinced his mother had  committed.
Why was he... dressed like that?
He's a transvestite!

Not exactly. A man who dresses in  woman's clothing in order to achieve  a sexual change... or satisfaction...  is a transvestite.  But in Norman's  case, he was simply doing everything  possible to keep alive the illusion  of his mother being alive. And  whenever reality came too close,  when danger or desire threatened  that illusion, he'd dress up, even  to a cheap wig he brought, and he'd  walk about the house, sit in her  chair, speak in her voice... He tried  to be his mother. (A sad smile)
And now he is. (A pause)

That's what I meant when I said I  got the story from the mother. She  thinks Norman has been taken away...  because of his crimes.  She insists  she did nothing, that Norman committed  all the murders just to keep her  from being discovered. She even smiled  a bit coquettishly as she said that.  Of course, she feels badly about  it... but also somewhat relieved to  be, as she put it, free of Norman,  at last. (A pause)

When the mind houses two  personalities, there is always a  battle. In Norman's case, the battle  is over... and the dominant  personality has won. Lila begins to weep softly, for Mary, for Arbogast, for  Norman, for all the destroyed human beings of this world. Sam bends beside her, puts his arm about her, comforts he
(To Simon)
And the forty thousand dollars?  Who  got that?
The swamp. These were murders of  passion, not profit. A POLICE GUARD puts his head in the door, speaks, in a ne whisper, to the Chief of Police. The Guard is carrying a  folded blanket over his arm.

He feels a little chill... can I  bring him this blanket? The Chief of Police nods. The Guard goes away, and CAMERA FOLLOWS him out of the room and out into the hallway. Gua moves through the waiting men, heading down the corridor.

A narrower corridor in the rear of the building. In f.g. shot, we see a door, the top half of which is wire-covere glass. A GUARD in uniform is posted by the door, looking  reprovingly at the two or three people trying to get a gl into the room. The Police Guard, carrying the blanket, comes down this  corridor, goes to the door. CAMERA MOVES CLOSE. The unifo Guard opens the door, allows the man to go in. Shot is RAKED so that we can not see into the room. After a moment, the Guard comes out and the uniformed Gua closes and locks the door and we

The walls are white and plain. There is no window. There is no furniture except the straight-back chair in w Norman sits, in the center of the room. The room has a qu of no-whereness, of calm separation from the world. The Police Guard has placed the blanket on Norman's knees Norman, as we come upon him, is lifting the blanket, unfo it. His face, although without makeup and without the  surrounding softness of the wig, has a certain femininity about it, a softness about the mouth and a kind of arch  womanliness about the brows. Calmly, Norman places the blanket about his shoulders, as it were a cashmere shawl. CAMERA REMAINS in a position so that our view of Norman is a FULL ONE. When the shawl is position, and Norman is settled, we HEAR, OVER SHOT, the  voice of his mother, coming from the calm of his thoughts
It's sad... when a mother has to  speak the words that condemn her own  son... but I couldn't allow them to  believe that I would commit murder. (A pause)

They'll put him away now... as I  should have... years ago. He was  always... bad. And in the end, he  intended to tell them I killed those  girls... and that man. As if I could  do anything except just sit and  stare... like one of his stuffed  birds. (A pause)

Well, they know I can't even move a  finger. And I won't. I'll just sit  here and be quiet. Just in case they  do... suspect me. A fly buzzes close, and then continues buzzing and flying about Norman's face.
They're probably watching me.  Well,  let them. Let them see what kind of  a person I am. (A pause, as the fly  lights on Norman's  hand)

I'm not going to swat that fly. I  hope they are watching. They'll see...  they'll see... and they'll know...  and they'll say... 'why, she wouldn't  even harm a fly...' Norman continues to gaze ahead into nothing.

head_text.speaker/title: SCENE BEGINS TO DISSOLVE SLOWLY TO:

text: As END TITLES FADE IN, we see the swamp, the chain of a t truck. The chain is attached to Mary's car. The car is co out of the swamp.
